# Model and Results Generalized Extended CMV Matrices Consider the Hilbert space ${\mathcal{H}}:=\ell^2({\mathbb{Z}})$ with the standard basis $\{\delta_n : n \in {\mathbb{Z}}\}$. On ${\mathcal{H}}$, we consider *generalized extended CMV matrices* $\mathcal{E} = \mathcal{E}(\alpha,\rho)$ defined by $\mathcal{E}=\mathcal{L}\mathcal{M}$, where $\mathcal{L}=\bigoplus_{n\in{\mathbb{Z}}}\Theta(\alpha_{2n},\rho_{2n})$ and $\mathcal{M}=\bigoplus_{n\in{\mathbb{Z}}}\Theta(\alpha_{2n+1},\rho_{2n+1})$ are specified by $$\label{eq:theta_mat} \Theta(\alpha,\rho)=\begin{bmatrix}\overline{\alpha}&\rho\\\overline{\rho}&-\alpha\end{bmatrix}$$ with Verblunsky pairs $$\label{eq:verblunsky_pair} (\alpha,\rho)\in{\mathbb{S}}^3=\{(z_1,z_2)\in\overline{\mathbb{D}}^2:|z_1|^2+|z_2|^2=1\}.$$ In the definitions of ${\mathcal{L}}$ and ${\mathcal{M}}$, we note that $\Theta(\alpha_j,\rho_j)$ acts on the subspace $\ell^2(\{j,j+1\})$. In the standard basis $\{\delta_n : n \in {\mathbb{Z}}\}$ of $\ell^2({\mathbb{Z}})$, such a GECMV matrix takes the form $$\label{eq:gecmv} \mathcal E = \begin{bmatrix} \ddots & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots &&&& \\ & \overline{\alpha_0\rho_{-1}} & \boxed{-\overline{\alpha_0}\alpha_{-1}} & \overline{\alpha_1}\rho_0 & \rho_1\rho_0 &&& \\ & \overline{\rho_0\rho_{-1}} & -\overline{\rho_0}\alpha_{-1} & {-\overline{\alpha_1}\alpha_0} & -\rho_1 \alpha_0 &&& \\ && & \overline{\alpha_2\rho_1} & -\overline{\alpha_2}\alpha_1 & \overline{\alpha_3} \rho_2 & \rho_3\rho_2 & \\ && & \overline{\rho_2\rho_1} & -\overline{\rho_2}\alpha_1 & -\overline{\alpha_3}\alpha_2 & -\rho_3\alpha_2 & \\ && && \ddots & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots & \end{bmatrix},$$ where we boxed the $(0,0)$ matrix element of ${\mathcal{E}}$.

“Generalized” here means that the $\rho$’s are allowed to take complex values inside the closed unit disk $\overline{\mathbb{D}}$, in contrast to *standard extended CMV matrices* as defined in , where the $\rho$’s merely take real values in $(0,1]$. Let us mention that this complexification of extended CMV matrices was originally motivated by physical models . Moreover, this class of operators is motivated by the study of split-step quantum walks whose quantum coins have determinant one; indeed, if one takes such a split step walk and writes down the matrix with respect to the ordered basis $$\ldots \delta_{-1}^-, \delta_0^+, \delta_0^-, \delta_1^+, \ldots,$$ then the associated matrix is exactly a GECMV matrix with suitable $(\alpha,\rho)$; see Section 3. As discussed in the introduction, this generalization turned out to be essential to the work since the complexification of the $\rho$ parameters (which was motivated by the choice of magnetic translations for an associated 2D model) was absolutely crucial to make room for the magic of duality, the Herman estimate, and other techniques. To study the spectral properties of $\mathcal{E}$, one naturally considers the generalized eigenvalue equation $\mathcal{E}u=zu$ for $z\in{\mathbb{C}}$. Solutions to this equation satisfy the iterative relation $$\begin{bmatrix}u_{2n+1}\\u_{2n}\end{bmatrix}=A_{n,z}\begin{bmatrix}u_{2n-1}\\u_{2n-2}\end{bmatrix}, \quad n \in {\mathbb{Z}},$$ where the *transfer matrices* $A_{n,z}$ are given by $$\label{eq:GECMV_transmat} A_{n,z}=\frac{1}{\rho_{2n}\rho_{2n-1}}\begin{bmatrix} z^{-1}+\alpha_{2n}\overline{\alpha}_{2n-1}+\alpha_{2n-1}\overline{\alpha}_{2n-2}+\alpha_{2n}\overline{\alpha}_{2n-2}z& -\overline{\rho}_{2n-2}\alpha_{2n-1}-\overline{\rho}_{2n-2}\alpha_{2n}z\\ -\rho_{2n}\overline{\alpha}_{2n-1}-\rho_{2n}\overline{\alpha}_{2n-2}z&\rho_{2n}\overline{\rho}_{2n-2}z \end{bmatrix},$$ for $n \in {\mathbb{Z}}$ and $z \in {\mathbb{C}}\setminus \{0\}$. This follows from direct calculations, which are carried out in detail in . We will relate isospectral families of GECMV matrices at two levels: First, we show that any two GECMV matrices with the same $\alpha$’s are unitarily equivalent via a diagonal unitary. Thus, the spectral type and properties of solutions to the eigenvalue equation are *independent* of the phase of the $\rho$’s. Second, later in the paper, we show how to relate the transfer matrix cocycle as in [eq:GECMV_transmat] to the the Szegő cocycle. These are also related to the Gesztesy–Zinchenko cocycle via an identity elucidated in , but we will not need that connection here. We give precise definitions of these objects later. We anticipate that these ideas and connections will be useful in other contexts.

We will relate isospectral families of GECMV matrices at two levels: First, we show that any two GECMV matrices with the same $\alpha$’s are unitarily equivalent via a diagonal unitary. Thus, the spectral type and properties of solutions to the eigenvalue equation are *independent* of the phase of the $\rho$’s. Second, later in the paper, we show how to relate the transfer matrix cocycle as in [eq:GECMV_transmat] to the the Szegő cocycle. These are also related to the Gesztesy–Zinchenko cocycle via an identity elucidated in , but we will not need that connection here. We give precise definitions of these objects later. We anticipate that these ideas and connections will be useful in other contexts.
**Theorem 1**. *Any two GECMV matrices with the same $\alpha$’s are unitarily equivalent, and thus isospectral. More precisely, given a set of Verblunsky coefficients $\{\alpha_{n}:n\in{\mathbb{Z}}\}\subset{\mathbb{D}}$, let $\rho_n=\sqrt{1-|\alpha_n|^2}$. Then, for any two sequences $\{\xi_{n}\}_n,\{\zeta_{n}\}_n\subset \partial {\mathbb{D}}$, the GECMVs $\mathcal E^\xi$ and $\mathcal E^\zeta$ associated to coefficient sequences $\{\alpha_{n},\xi_{n}\rho_n\}$ and $\{\alpha_{n},\zeta_{n}\rho_n\}$, respectively, are gauge equivalent, i.e., there exists a diagonal unitary matrix $D$ so that $\mathcal E^\xi=D^*\mathcal E^\zeta D$.*
**Remark 2**. Verblunsky’s Theorem (also called Favard’s Theorem on the circle, compare, ) sets up a one-to-one correspondence $\mu\leftrightarrow\{\alpha_{n}\}_{n=0}^{\infty}$ between non-trivial probability measures on the unit circle $\partial{\mathbb{D}}$ and $\bigtimes_{j=0}^{\infty}{\mathbb{D}}$. This correspondence does not care about the values of $\rho_{n}$’s. Theorem 1 shows the isospectral nature of GECMVs associated to the *phased* $\rho_{n}$’s.
This immediately implies that every GECMV matrix can be turned into a standard extended CMV matrix. This requires transforming the $\rho$’s to nonnegative real numbers, which can be achieved via a diagonal gauge transformation, and thus generalizes the technique in :

**Corollary 3**. *Every GECMV matrix is gauge-equivalent to a standard extended CMV matrix. More precisely, for any GECMV matrix $\mathcal E$ determined by Verblunsky pairs $(\alpha_k,\rho_k)_{k\in{\mathbb{Z}}}$, there is a diagonal unitary operator $D$ such that $D^*\mathcal ED$ is a standard extended CMV matrix with Verblunsky pairs $(\alpha_k,|\rho_k|)_{k\in{\mathbb{Z}}}$.*
**Remark 4**. The matrix form of $\mathcal E$ given in [eq:gecmv] and the condition [eq:verblunsky_pair] are essential for the the ability to choose the diagonal conjugation in such a way that the $\alpha$’s remain fixed. As discussed above, this corresponds to split-step walks with unimodular coins. In the more general setting, one is led to operators such that $|\alpha|^2+|\rho|^2\in \partial {\mathbb{D}}$; see Appendix 9 for details. Here, one has to be slightly more careful, but the basic idea still works; compare . As a word of warning, however, it is sometimes not possible to choose the gauge in such a manner as to fix the $\alpha$’s in this general setting, and in particular, the *base dynamics* may no longer be gauge invariant within the class of isospectral GECMV. For instance, the CMV matrix corresponding to the quasi-periodic quantum walk in is not quasi-periodic anymore; instead, its Verblunsky coefficients are generated by the skew-shift.

As discussed above, one of the pleasant outcomes of this approach is that it enables us to deal with reflection symmetries in a useful way. See Section [sec:reflection] for detailed statements, and note that the desired reflection symmetry for the $\rho$ terms is given by [eq.newReflectionProp], which forces one to consider $\rho$ values outside of $[0,1]$. We anticipate that this perspective will lead to useful results in other contexts. Almost-periodic GECMV matrices

Almost-periodic GECMV matrices Our work is motivated by the study of certain almost-periodic (but not quasi-periodic) quantum walks, which lead to the following GECMV matrices. We will explain the origin of this model in Section 3. We here consider a model where all even Verblunsky pairs are constant, every $s$-th odd one is given by a quasi-periodic function, and all others are “trivial” from a dynamical perspective. Concretely, let $\theta,\Phi\in\mathbb{T}$, and $\lambda_1,\lambda_2\in[0,1]$, and consider $$\label{eq:mosaicVerblunskieS} \begin{alignedat}{4} (\alpha_{2n-1},\rho_{2n-1})&=\begin{cases} (\lambda_{2}\sin2\pi(\theta+n\Phi),\lambda_{2}\cos2\pi(\theta+n\Phi)-i\lambda_{2}'),& n\in s{\mathbb{Z}},\\ (0,-i),& n\in {\mathbb{Z}}\backslash s{\mathbb{Z}}, \end{cases}\\ (\alpha_{2n},\rho_{2n})&=(\lambda_1',\lambda_1),\qquad n\in{\mathbb{Z}}, \end{alignedat}$$ where $\lambda_{i}'=\sqrt{1-\lambda_{i}^{2}},i=1,2$. The case $s=1$ corresponds to the *unitary almost-Mathieu operator (UAMO)* and was studied extensively in . For reasons that will become clear later, we will call GECMV matrices with coefficients as in [eq:mosaicVerblunskies] the *mosaic UAMO* (see Section 3) and denote them by $\mathcal E_{\Phi,\lambda_1,\lambda_2,s}(\theta)$ or $\mathcal E(\theta)$ for short when all parameters are fixed.

**Theorem 5**. * Fix $\Phi \in {\mathrm{DC}}$ and $\lambda_1,\lambda_2 \in (0,1)$, satisfying $$\label{eq:lambdacond} \frac{\lambda_1^2}{\lambda_1'} < \frac{2\lambda_2}{\lambda_2'}.$$ For each $\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}$, define $\alpha = \alpha(\theta)$ and $\rho = \rho(\theta)$ by [eq:mosaicVerblunskies] and consider the associated GECMV matrix $\mathcal{E}(\theta):= \mathcal{E}(\alpha(\theta), \rho(\theta))$ as in [eq:gecmv]. Choose $t_0 \in (0,\pi/2)$ such that $$\label{eq:t0DEF} \cos(t_{0})=\frac{\lambda_{1}^{2}\lambda_{2}'}{2\lambda_{1}'\lambda_{2}}.$$ Then, for any $\xi=\{\xi_n:n\in{\mathbb{Z}}\}\subset\partial{\mathbb{D}}$,* 1. * $\mathcal{E}^\xi(\theta)$ has purely absolutely continuous spectrum in $$I_{\mathrm{ac}}:= (e^{-it_0+\pi/2},e^{it_0+\pi/2})\cup(e^{-it_0-\pi/2},e^{it_0-\pi/2})$$ for every $\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}$.* 2. *$\mathcal{E}^\xi(\theta)$ exhibits Anderson localization in $$I_{\mathrm{pp}}:= (e^{it_0 - \pi/2}, e^{-it_0+\pi/2}) \cup (e^{it_0+\pi/2},e^{-it_0-\pi/2})$$ for every $\theta$ that is non-resonant with respect to $\Phi$ (in particular, for a.e. $\theta$).*
**Remark 6**.

**Remark 6**. 1. To the best of our knowledge, this gives the first explicit example of almost-periodic (GE)CMV matrices/quantum walks enjoying an exact mobility edge. Part (b) is of particular interest. Recalling Corollary 3, this gives the first family of almost-periodic extended CMV matrices that has Anderson localization for fixed frequency. 2. The condition on the coupling constant $\lambda_1$ and $\lambda_2$ in the statement of the theorem ensures that there is a genuine mobility edge, i.e. that $t_0$ is well-defined. 3. The reader may consult Figure [fig:phasediagram] for an illustration of the different spectral regions for varying coupling constants, and Figure [fig:mobility_edges] for numerical simulation thereof. 4. We compute exactly the Lyapunov exponent on the spectrum (see Theorem 12 for a detailed statement) and show that the eigenfunctions decay at the Lyapunov rate (see Theorem 32)

# Physical Motivation: The Mosaic UAMO

Let us describe the physical model that motivates both our study of GECMV matrices and of mobility edges for the mosaic UAMO, that is, one-dimensional quantum walks of split-step type. These systems are specified by a generalized shift and a coin sequence, which for the mosaic UAMO alternates between a quasi-periodic coin and $s-1$ perfectly transmitting coins. The generalized shift as well as the quasi-periodic coin sequences are derived from the *unitary almost-Mathieu operator* (UAMO) which describes the discrete time evolution of a particle on two-dimensional lattice with perpendicular magnetic field .

Let $\mathscr{H}=\ell^{2}({\mathbb{Z}})\otimes {\mathbb{C}}^{2}$. On this Hilbert space, we consider a *split-step quantum walk* $W:\mathscr{H}\to\mathscr{H}$ that is given as a product of a conditional shift operator that additionally depends on a *coupling constant* and a coin operator. To define these operators, let us write the standard basis of $\mathscr{H}$ as $$\label{eq:base}
        \delta_{n}^{s}=\delta_{n}\otimes e_{s},\quad n\in{\mathbb{Z}},s\in\{+,-\},$$ where $\{\delta_{n}:n\in{\mathbb{Z}}\}$ is the standard basis of $\ell^{2}({\mathbb{Z}})$ and $\{e_{+}=(1,0)^{\top}, \ e_{-}=(0,1)^{\top}\}$ is the standard basis of ${\mathbb{C}}^{2}$. With respect to this basis, we denote the coordinates of an element $\psi\in\mathscr H$ as $\psi_n^s=\langle\delta^s_n,\psi\rangle$, so that $\psi=\sum\nolimits_{n\in{\mathbb{Z}}}\psi_{n}^{+}\delta_{n}^{+}+\psi_{n}^{-}\delta_{n}^{-}$.

In the same spirit, plugging the Verblunsky coefficients from [eq:mosaicVerblunskies] into [GECMV] identifies the GECMV matrix $\mathcal E(\theta)$ defined in [eq:mosaicVerblunskies] as a *mosaic model* derived from the UAMO with local coins determined by $$\label{eq:mosaic_coins} \begin{aligned} Q_n &=\begin{dcases}\begin{bmatrix}\lambda_2\cos(2\pi(n\Phi+\theta))+i\lambda_2'&-\lambda_2\sin(2\pi(n\Phi+\theta))\\ \lambda_2 \sin(2\pi(n\Phi+\theta)) & \lambda_2\cos(2\pi(n\Phi+\theta)) - i\lambda_2'\end{bmatrix} & n \in s{\mathbb{Z}}\\[5mm] \begin{bmatrix}i&0\\0&-i\end{bmatrix} & n \in {\mathbb{Z}}\setminus s {\mathbb{Z}}.\end{dcases} \end{aligned}$$ Here, $s \geq 1$ is a fixed integer that determines the “step size”: every $s$-th coin is the same as in the UAMO, and all others are replaced by perfectly transmitting coins. More precisely, we set $\lambda_2=0$ at lattice sites $n\notin s{\mathbb{Z}}= \{s m : m \in {\mathbb{Z}}\}$. The resulting walk $W = S_{\lambda_1}Q$ with coin operator $Q = Q_{\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta,s}$ corresponding to the sequence of local coins defined in [eq:mosaic_coins] will be denoted $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta,s}$. This model can be thought of as a unitary analogue of the almost-periodic mosaic model studied in , that is, the discrete Schrödinger operator $H_{V,\Phi,\theta}$ with onsite potential $$V_n =\begin{cases} 2\lambda \cos(2\pi(n\Phi+\theta)),& n \in s{\mathbb{Z}}\\ 0,& n \in {\mathbb{Z}}\setminus s {\mathbb{Z}}. \end{cases}$$ In view of the connection between the AMO and the UAMO, we thus call $W_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,\Phi,\theta,s}$ the *mosaic unitary almost-Mathieu operator*, or the *mosaic UAMO* for short. In contrast to the UAMO, the coin sequence for the mosaic UAMO is almost-periodic, but no longer quasi-periodic. However, we can still recover quasi-periodicity in the study of the eigenvalue equation by passing to steps of length $s$, an idea which has been fruitfully applied in several similar models, see, e.g. .
**Remark 7**. Let us make a few comments.

**Remark 7**. Let us make a few comments. 1. With the single coupling constant of the AMO being replaced by two independent coupling constants for the UAMO, one might be tempted to consider another mosaic model by setting $\lambda_1=1$ at every $s$-th site. However, as noted in the quantity that most closely parallels the coupling constant of the AMO is $$\lambda_0=\lambda_0(\lambda_1,\lambda_2):=\frac{\lambda_2(1+\lambda_1')}{\lambda_1(1+\lambda_2')}.$$ In view of this, the only way to make $\lambda_0$ vanish within the admitted parameter ranges $\lambda_1,\lambda_2\in[0,1]$ is to set $\lambda_2=0$, which motivates the definition of the mosaic model that we use here. 2. Setting $s=1$ in [eq:mosaic_coins] one recovers exactly the UAMO from . Theorem [thm:mobs] thus shows that the mosaic UAMO exhibits an explicit mobility edge for suitable choices of the parameters. As said before, this gives a new type of phase transition in the world of one-dimensional quasi-periodic quantum walk operators: a phase transition in the spectral parameter.

# Generalized Extended CMV Matrices Gauge transformation We first prove that the phases of the $\rho$’s that define a GECMV matrix can be freely changed via a diagonal gauge transformation:
*Proof of Theorem 1..* First, note that to prove the statement it is sufficient to show that any GECMV matrix $\mathcal E$ with Verblunsky coefficients $\alpha_n$ can be transformed by a diagonal unitary into a “reference” GECMV matrix $\mathcal E_0$ with the same $\alpha$’s. This readily implies the statement by combining two such steps: if $\mathcal E^\xi$ and $\mathcal E^\chi$ are two such GECMV matrices with $D_\xi^*\mathcal E^\xi D_\xi=\mathcal E_0$ and $D_\chi^*\mathcal E^\chi D_\chi=\mathcal E_0$, respectively, then $\mathcal E^\xi=D_\xi D_\chi^*\mathcal E^\chi D_\chi D_\xi^*$. A particularly natural choice for $\mathcal E_0$ turns out to be the standard extended CMV matrix with Verblunksy coefficients $\alpha_n$ and $\rho_n=\sqrt{1-|\alpha_n|^2}$.

Reflection Symmetries Consider the GECMV matrix in [eq:gecmv] with Verblunsky pairs $(\alpha_{j},\rho_{j})$. For $k \in {\mathbb{Z}}$, let $R_{k}$ be the unitary involution on $\ell^2({\mathbb{Z}})$ that reflects through the center $c=k+\tfrac{1}{2}$, that is, $R_k:\delta_n \mapsto \delta_{-n+2k+1}$. In particular, $R_k:\delta_{2n-1} \mapsto \delta_{2(-n+k)}$ and $R_k:\delta_{2n} \mapsto \delta_{2(-n+k)+1}$. Notice that $R_{k}$ maps $\ell^2(\{-n,\ldots,n+2c\})$ to itself.
**Definition 8** (Reflection). We call $\mathcal{E}^{\mathscr{R}} :=R_{k}\mathcal{E}R_{k}$ the *reflection* of $\mathcal{E}$ with center $c=k+1/2$. One can check that $\mathcal{E}^{\mathscr{R}}$ is obtained from $\mathcal E$ by exchanging the positions of the elements that are symmetric with respect to the center of the square $$\left[\begin{array}{c|c} -\overline{\alpha_{k}}\alpha_{k-1}&\overline{\alpha_{k+1}}\rho_{k}\\ \hline -\overline{\rho_{k}}\alpha_{k-1}&-\overline{\alpha_{k+1}}\alpha_{k} \end{array}\right]$$ when $k$ is even, and $$\left[\begin{array}{c|c} -\overline{\alpha_{k}}\alpha_{k-1}&\alpha_{k-1}\rho_{k}\\ \hline -\overline{\rho_{k}}\overline{\alpha_{k+1}}&-\overline{\alpha_{k+1}}\alpha_{k} \end{array}\right]$$ when $k$ is odd.
**Remark 9**.

**Remark 9**. 1. We restrict ourselves to centers from $\frac{1}{2}+{\mathbb{Z}}$. This is mostly for convenience so that the reflected GECMV matrix is again a GECMV matrix. If one reflects through an integer center, the reflected matrix is the *transpose* of a GECMV matrix. 2. In the quantum walks language of Section 3, if $k$ is even, the center of reflection lies “between” the cells at $k$ and $k+1$, whereas if $k$ is odd, the center of reflection lies “within” the cell at $k$. A direct consequence of this definition is that $\mathcal E$ and $\mathcal E^\mathscr{R}$ have the same spectrum with similar statements for suitable finite cutoffs. In particular, for the finite restriction (or “cutoff” GECMV matrix ) $\mathcal{E}|_{[-n,n+2c]}$ one has for the reflection $\mathcal E^\mathscr{R}$ with center $c$ that $$\label{eq.determinant} \det(z\mathbbm{1}-\mathcal{E}|_{[-n,n+2c]}^{\mathscr{R}})=\det(z\mathbbm{1}-\mathcal{E}|_{[-n,n+2c]}).$$

A direct consequence of this definition is that $\mathcal E$ and $\mathcal E^\mathscr{R}$ have the same spectrum with similar statements for suitable finite cutoffs. In particular, for the finite restriction (or “cutoff” GECMV matrix ) $\mathcal{E}|_{[-n,n+2c]}$ one has for the reflection $\mathcal E^\mathscr{R}$ with center $c$ that $$\label{eq.determinant} \det(z\mathbbm{1}-\mathcal{E}|_{[-n,n+2c]}^{\mathscr{R}})=\det(z\mathbbm{1}-\mathcal{E}|_{[-n,n+2c]}).$$ Let us see how one can take advantage of some of these ideas in the setting of GECMV matrices generated by sampling functions with suitable symmetries. Concretely, assume that $\{\mathcal{E}(\theta)\}_{\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}} = \{\mathcal{E}(\alpha(\theta), \rho(\theta)\}_{\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}}$ is a family of GECMV matrices that depends on the variable $\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}$, and let us furthermore assume that the coefficients possess the following reflection property with respect to the reflection center $c$: $$\label{eq.newReflectionProp} \alpha_{-n+2c}(\theta)=\overline{\alpha_{n+2c}(-\theta)},\quad \rho_{-n+2c}(\theta)=-\overline{\rho_{n+2c}(-\theta)}.$$ Then, the corresponding GECMV matrix $\mathcal{E}(\theta)$ satisfies $\mathcal{E}^{\mathscr{R}}(\theta)=S^{-2(k+1)}\mathcal{E}(-\theta)S^{2(k+1)}$ where $S:\delta_n\mapsto\delta_{n+1}$ denotes the bilateral shift on $\ell^2({\mathbb{Z}})$. That is, reflecting with center $c=k+1/2$ is equivalent to shifting by $2(k+1)$ up to a sign-change of $\theta$. This yields the following result:
**Proposition 10**. *Let $\mathcal E(\theta)$ be a GECMV matrix with Verblunsky coefficients satisfying [eq.newReflectionProp] for $c=-1/2$. Then $\det(z\mathbbm{1}-\mathcal{E}(\theta)|_{[-n,n-1]})$ is an even function of $\theta\in{\mathbb{T}}$.*

*Proof.* As a consequence of the reflection pairs above, [eq.determinant] and [eq.newReflectionProp] we have $$\label{eq.deterEveness1} \det(z\mathbbm{1}-\mathcal{E}(\theta)|_{[-n,n-1]})=\det(z\mathbbm{1}-\mathcal{E}^{\mathscr{R}}(\theta)|_{[-n,n-1]})(\theta)=\det(z\mathbbm{1}-\mathcal{E}(-\theta)|_{[-n,n-1]}).$$ ◻
We shall apply this result in Section 6 to prove localization of the mosaic UAMO in the supercritical regime. We remark that when applied to the UAMO from , Proposition 10 provides an alternate proof for .

# Cocycle Dynamics and Lyapunov Exponents A crucial ingredient in the study of the properties of a GECMV matrix is the classification of cocycle behavior via Avila’s global theory of one-frequency analytic cocycles . We first review this theory and then show the equivalence between transfer matrix cocycles as defined in [eq:GECMV_transmat] and Szegő cocycles. This will provide the necessary tools to calculate the Lyapunov exponent on the spectrum. Review of Avila’s global theory

Review of Avila’s global theory Given $\Phi$ irrational and $M:{\mathbb{T}}\to{\mathbb{M}}(2,{\mathbb{C}})$ continuous, consider the skew product $$\label{eq:qp_cocycle} (\Phi,M):{\mathbb{T}}\times{\mathbb{C}}^2\to{\mathbb{T}}\times{\mathbb{C}}^2,\qquad (\theta,v)\mapsto(\theta+\Phi,M(\theta)v).$$ The iterates of this *quasi-periodic cocycle* are given by $(\Phi,M)^n=(n\Phi,M^n)$ where for $n\in{\mathbb{N}}$ $$M^n(\theta)=M^{n,\Phi}(\theta)=\prod_{j=n-1}^0M(\theta+j\Phi).$$ The *Lyapunov exponent* of the cocycle $(\Phi,M)$ is defined by $$L(\Phi,M)=\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac1n\int_{\mathbb{T}}\log\|M^{n,\Phi}(\theta)\| d\theta.$$ If $M$ is analytic with an analytic extension to a strip ${\mathbb{T}}_\delta := \{\theta+i\epsilon:|\epsilon|<\delta\}$, for $|\epsilon|<\delta$ we may consider the complexified cocycle $M(\cdot+i\epsilon):\theta\mapsto M(\theta+i\epsilon)$ and define $L(\Phi, M,\epsilon)$ as the Lyapunov exponent associated with the complexified cocycle map $M(\cdot + i\epsilon)$, that is, $$L(\Phi, M, \epsilon)=L(\Phi, M(\cdot+i\epsilon)).$$ Under the analyticity assumption, we define the *acceleration* for $|\eta|<\delta$ by $$\omega(\Phi, M, \eta):=\lim_{\epsilon\downarrow0}\frac1{2\pi\epsilon}(L(\Phi,M,\eta+\epsilon)-L(\Phi,M,\eta)),$$ and abbreviate $$\omega(\Phi, M):= \omega(\Phi,M,0) = \lim_{\epsilon\downarrow0}\frac1{2\pi\epsilon}(L(\Phi,M,\epsilon)-L(\Phi,M)).$$ A central property of the acceleration that we shall need further below is its quantization, that is, $$\omega(\Phi, M, \eta)\in\tfrac12{\mathbb{Z}}$$ for all $|\eta|<\delta$ . Moreover, if $M(\theta)\in{\mathbb{SL}}(2,{\mathbb{C}})$ for all $\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}$, we have $\omega(\Phi, M, \eta)\in{\mathbb{Z}}$ for all $|\eta|<\delta$.

A central property of the acceleration that we shall need further below is its quantization, that is, $$\omega(\Phi, M, \eta)\in\tfrac12{\mathbb{Z}}$$ for all $|\eta|<\delta$ . Moreover, if $M(\theta)\in{\mathbb{SL}}(2,{\mathbb{C}})$ for all $\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}$, we have $\omega(\Phi, M, \eta)\in{\mathbb{Z}}$ for all $|\eta|<\delta$. A ${\mathbb{SL}}(2,{\mathbb{C}})$-cocycle $(\Phi,M)$ is called *uniformly hyperbolic* if for some constants $c,\lambda>0$ one has $$\|M^n(\theta)\| \geq ce^{\lambda | n |}$$ uniformly in $n \in {\mathbb{Z}}$ and $\theta \in {\mathbb{T}}$. From the spectral perspective, uniform hyperbolicity corresponds to the resolvent set of the underlying operator in the sense that a given spectral parameter $z$ belongs to the resolvent set if and only if the associated transfer matrix cocycle is uniformly hyperbolic ; see also .
**Definition 11**. Assume that $(\Phi,M)$ is a ${\mathbb{SU}}(1,1)$ cocycle that is not uniformly hyperbolic. Then $(\Phi,M)$ is said to be 1. *Supercritical*, if $L(\Phi,M)>0$. 2. *Subcritical*, if there exists $\epsilon_0>0$ such that $L(\Phi, M,\epsilon)=0$ for all $\epsilon$ with $|\epsilon|<\epsilon_{0}.$ 3. *Critical*; otherwise.

Calculations of Lyapunov exponent In this section, we compute the Lyapunov exponent of the mosaic UAMO model. Let us first introduce the basic notations and definitions: For the mosaic UAMO with $s=2$ and Verblunsky coefficients given in [eq:mosaicVerblunskies], the transfer matrices from [eq:GECMV_transmat] take the form: $$\begin{aligned}\label{evenA} A_{2n,z}=&\frac{1}{\lambda_{2}\cos2\pi(\theta+2n\Phi)-i\lambda_{2}'}\\ &\times\begin{bmatrix} \lambda_{1}^{-1}z^{-1}+2\lambda_{1}^{-1}\lambda_{1}'\lambda_{2}\sin2\pi(\theta+2 n\Phi)+\lambda_{1}^{-1}{\lambda_{1}'}^{2}z&-\lambda_{2}\sin2\pi(\theta+2 n\Phi)-\lambda_{1}'z\\ -\lambda_{2}\sin2\pi(\theta+2 n\Phi)-\lambda_{1}'z&\lambda_{1}z \end{bmatrix}, \end{aligned}$$ and $$\label{oddA} \begin{aligned} A_{2n+1,z}&= i\begin{bmatrix} \lambda_{1}^{-1}z^{-1}+\lambda_{1}^{-1}{\lambda_{1}'}^{2}z&-\lambda_{1}'z\\ -\lambda_{1}'z&\lambda_{1}z \end{bmatrix}. \end{aligned}$$ These transfer matrices naturally define a *transfer matrix cocycle* of the form above: define $A_{\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},z}: {\mathbb{T}}\to {\mathbb{C}}^{2\times 2}$ by $$\label{eq.transferMatrix} A_{\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},z}(\theta)=\frac{1}{\lambda_{2}{\mathrm{c}}(\theta)-i\lambda_{2}'} \begin{bmatrix} \lambda_{1}^{-1}z^{-1}+2\lambda_{1}^{-1}\lambda_{1}'\lambda_{2}{\mathrm{s}}(\theta)+\lambda_{1}^{-1}{\lambda_{1}'}^{2}z&-\lambda_{2}{\mathrm{s}}(\theta)-\lambda_{1}'z\\ -\lambda_{2}{\mathrm{s}}(\theta)-\lambda_{1}'z&\lambda_{1}z \end{bmatrix},$$ where we adopted the notation $$\label{eq:cstwopi} {\mathrm{c}}(\theta)=\cos(2\pi\theta),\qquad{\mathrm{s}}(\theta)=\sin(2\pi\theta).$$ With this definition, one readily checks that $$A_{2n,z} = A_{\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},z}(\theta+2n\Phi), \qquad A_{2n+1,z}=A_{\lambda_{1},0,z}(\theta + 2n\Phi).$$ We remark that this construction generalizes in a straightforward fashion to $s>2$.

Calculations of Lyapunov exponent In this section, we compute the Lyapunov exponent of the mosaic UAMO model. Let us first introduce the basic notations and definitions: For the mosaic UAMO with $s=2$ and Verblunsky coefficients given in [eq:mosaicVerblunskies], the transfer matrices from [eq:GECMV_transmat] take the form: $$\begin{aligned}\label{evenA} A_{2n,z}=&\frac{1}{\lambda_{2}\cos2\pi(\theta+2n\Phi)-i\lambda_{2}'}\\ &\times\begin{bmatrix} \lambda_{1}^{-1}z^{-1}+2\lambda_{1}^{-1}\lambda_{1}'\lambda_{2}\sin2\pi(\theta+2 n\Phi)+\lambda_{1}^{-1}{\lambda_{1}'}^{2}z&-\lambda_{2}\sin2\pi(\theta+2 n\Phi)-\lambda_{1}'z\\ -\lambda_{2}\sin2\pi(\theta+2 n\Phi)-\lambda_{1}'z&\lambda_{1}z \end{bmatrix}, \end{aligned}$$ and $$\label{oddA} \begin{aligned} A_{2n+1,z}&= i\begin{bmatrix} \lambda_{1}^{-1}z^{-1}+\lambda_{1}^{-1}{\lambda_{1}'}^{2}z&-\lambda_{1}'z\\ -\lambda_{1}'z&\lambda_{1}z \end{bmatrix}. \end{aligned}$$ These transfer matrices naturally define a *transfer matrix cocycle* of the form above: define $A_{\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},z}: {\mathbb{T}}\to {\mathbb{C}}^{2\times 2}$ by $$\label{eq.transferMatrix} A_{\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},z}(\theta)=\frac{1}{\lambda_{2}{\mathrm{c}}(\theta)-i\lambda_{2}'} \begin{bmatrix} \lambda_{1}^{-1}z^{-1}+2\lambda_{1}^{-1}\lambda_{1}'\lambda_{2}{\mathrm{s}}(\theta)+\lambda_{1}^{-1}{\lambda_{1}'}^{2}z&-\lambda_{2}{\mathrm{s}}(\theta)-\lambda_{1}'z\\ -\lambda_{2}{\mathrm{s}}(\theta)-\lambda_{1}'z&\lambda_{1}z \end{bmatrix},$$ where we adopted the notation $$\label{eq:cstwopi} {\mathrm{c}}(\theta)=\cos(2\pi\theta),\qquad{\mathrm{s}}(\theta)=\sin(2\pi\theta).$$ With this definition, one readily checks that $$A_{2n,z} = A_{\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},z}(\theta+2n\Phi), \qquad A_{2n+1,z}=A_{\lambda_{1},0,z}(\theta + 2n\Phi).$$ We remark that this construction generalizes in a straightforward fashion to $s>2$. In order to formulate results for a genuine quasi-periodic cocycle instead of the merely almost-periodic $A_z$, let us define the two-step cocycle map by $$\label{eq:twoblockAzdef} A^{+}_z(\theta) \equiv A^{+}_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}(\theta) := A_{\lambda_1,0,z}(\theta) A_{\lambda_1,\lambda_2,z}(\theta).$$ From the definitions, $A^+_z$ establishes a quasi-periodic cocycle in the sense of [eq:qp_cocycle], i.e., $$(2\Phi,A_z^+): {\mathbb{T}}\times {\mathbb{C}}^2 \to {\mathbb{T}}\times {\mathbb{C}}^2, \quad (x,v)\mapsto (x+2\Phi, A_z^+(x) v).$$ From the definitions above, the reader can confirm that its iterates are given by $$\label{eq:twoblockAzprod} A_{2n-1,z} \cdots A_{1,z}A_{0,z} = \prod_{j=n-1}^0 A^{+}_z(\theta+ 2j\Phi).$$ Consequentially, the *Lyapunov exponent* associated to the mosaic UAMO is defined to be half of the Lyapunov exponent of the quasi-periodic cocycle $(2\Phi,A^{+}_z)$, that is, $$\label{eq:mosaicLEDef} L(z) = \frac{1}{2} L(2\Phi,A^{+}_z) = \lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{1}{2n} \int_{{\mathbb{T}}} \log\|A^{+}_z(\theta+2(n-1)\Phi) \cdots A^{+}_z(\theta)\| \, d\theta.$$

**Theorem 12**. *For $s=2$, any $\lambda_1,\lambda_2 \in (0,1)$, $\Phi \in {\mathbb{R}}\backslash {\mathbb{Q}}$, and $e^{it}\in \Sigma_{\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},\Phi,2}$, the Lyapunov exponent of the associated mosaic UAMO model is given by $$\label{lya} L(e^{it}) = \frac{1}{2} \max\left\{0,F(\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},t)\right\},$$ where we denote $$F(\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},t)=\log\left[\frac{\lambda_{2}}{\lambda_{1}^{2}(1+\lambda_{2}')}\left(2\lambda_{1}'|\cos t|+\sqrt{\lambda_{1}^{4}+4{\lambda_{1}'}^{2}\cos^{2}t}\right)\right].$$ Moreover, for any $e^{it}\in \Sigma_{\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},\Phi ,2}$, the cocycle $(2\Phi,A^{+}_{e^{it}})$ is* 1. **subcritical* if and only if $F(\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},t)<0$.* 2. **critical* if and only if $F(\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},t)=0$.* 3. **supercritical* if and only if $F(\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},t)>0$.*
According to Corollary 3, it suffices to compute the Lyapunov exponents for the corresponding extended CMV matrix. Although the calculations can be done with the initial cocycle maps $A^{+}_{z}$, it is more convenient to put the question into ${\mathbb{SU}}(1,1)$ which allows one to directly apply Avila’s global theory:

**Lemma 13**. *Given $(\alpha,\rho)$ and $z\in\partial{\mathbb{D}}$, let $A_{n,z}$ be the transfer matrix cocycle given by [eq:GECMV_transmat] with $\rho_n$ replaced by $|\rho_n|$. Then we have the following: $$\label{eq.ConjugatedTransferMatrix} A_{n,z}=R_{2n}^{-1}JS^{+}_{n,z}JR_{2n-2},$$ where $S^{+}_{n,z}=S_{2n,z}S_{2n-1,z}$ is determined by the *normalized Szegő cocycle maps* $$\label{eq:szego_normalized} S_{n,z}=\frac{z^{-\frac{1}{2}}}{|\rho_{n}|}\begin{bmatrix}z&-\overline{\alpha_{n}}\\-\alpha_{n}z&1\end{bmatrix} \in {\mathbb{SU}}(1,1),$$ and $$R_{n}=\begin{bmatrix}1&0\\-\overline{\alpha_{n}}& |\rho_{n}| \end{bmatrix},\qquad J=\begin{bmatrix}0&1\\1&0\end{bmatrix}.$$*
*Proof.* This follows from a direct computation. ◻

Due to [eq.ConjugatedTransferMatrix], it suffices to consider the four-step combined quasi-periodic cocycle $(2\Phi,S^{++}_{z})$ instead of $(2\Phi,A^{+}_{z})$, where $$\label{eq.combinedSzego} S^{++}_{n,z} =S^{++}_{z}(\theta+2n\Phi)=S^{+}_{2n+1,z}S^{+}_{2n,z}.$$ By direct calculations, one verifies that $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq.zgo4steps} S^{++}_{z}(\theta)&=\frac{\lambda_{1}^{-2}}{|\lambda_{2}{\mathrm{c}}(\theta)-i\lambda_{2}'|}\begin{bmatrix} {\lambda_{1}'}^{2}+z^{2}+\lambda_{1}'\lambda_{2}(z+z^{-1}){\mathrm{s}}(\theta)&-\lambda_{1}'(1+z^{-2})-\lambda_{2}{\mathrm{s}}(\theta) (z+{\lambda_{1}'}^{2}z^{-1})\\ -\lambda_{1}'(1+z^{2})-\lambda_{2}{\mathrm{s}}(\theta) (z^{-1}+{\lambda_{1}'}^{2}z)&{\lambda_{1}'}^{2}+z^{-2}+\lambda_{1}'\lambda_{2}(z+z^{-1}){\mathrm{s}}(\theta) \end{bmatrix}\\ &=:\frac{\lambda_{1}^{-2}}{|\lambda_{2}{\mathrm{c}}(\theta)-i\lambda_{2}'|}\;M_{z}(\theta).\label{eq:defMz} \end{aligned}$$ We denote $$\begin{aligned} w(\theta) = |\lambda_2 {\mathrm{c}}(\theta) - i\lambda_2'| = \sqrt{\lambda_2^2 {\mathrm{c}}^2(\theta) + 1-\lambda_2^2} = \sqrt{1-\lambda_2^2 {\mathrm{s}}^2(\theta)}.

We denote $$\begin{aligned} w(\theta) = |\lambda_2 {\mathrm{c}}(\theta) - i\lambda_2'| = \sqrt{\lambda_2^2 {\mathrm{c}}^2(\theta) + 1-\lambda_2^2} = \sqrt{1-\lambda_2^2 {\mathrm{s}}^2(\theta)}. \end{aligned}$$ Note that the analytic extension of $S^{++}_{z}(\theta)$ is $M_{z}(\theta+i\epsilon)/(\lambda_{1}^{2}w(\theta+i\epsilon))$ and not $M_{z}(\theta+i\epsilon)/(\lambda_{1}^{2}(\lambda_{2}{\mathrm{c}}(\theta+i\epsilon)-i\lambda_{2}'))$. This could affect calculations of the matrix norm, since, for $\epsilon \neq 0$, one can check that $|w(\theta+i\epsilon)|$ and $|\lambda_2 {\mathrm{c}}(\theta+i\epsilon) - i \lambda_2'|$ need not coincide. To calculate the Lyapunov exponent of the cocycle $(2\Phi,S^{++}_{z})$, we first deal with the normalizing factor in front. By inspection, $w(\theta)$ is real-analytic on ${\mathbb{T}}$, and has an analytic extension to the strip $|\epsilon| < \frac{1}{2\pi} \mathop{\mathrm{arcsinh}}\sqrt{\lambda_2^{-2}-1}$ given by $${w}(\theta+i\epsilon) = \sqrt{1-\lambda_2^2 {\mathrm{s}}^2(\theta + i\epsilon)}.$$ Thus, this is the expression whose integral one needs to calculate:
**Lemma 14**. *Given $0 \le t \leq 1$, denote $t' = \sqrt{1-t^2}$ and $\epsilon_0 = \epsilon_0(t)= \tfrac{1}{2\pi} \mathop{\mathrm{arcsinh}}(t'/t)$. Then $$\begin{aligned} \int_0^1 \log\left| \sqrt{1-t^2 {\mathrm{s}}^2(\theta + i\epsilon)} \right| \, d\theta &= \begin{dcases} \log\left[\frac{1+t'}{2} \right]-2\pi(\epsilon+\epsilon_0) &\epsilon\leq-\epsilon_0,\\ \log\left[\frac{1+t'}{2} \right] & -\epsilon_0\leq\epsilon\leq\epsilon_0,\\ \log\left[\frac{1+t'}{2} \right]+2\pi(\epsilon-\epsilon_0) &\epsilon\geq\epsilon_0, \end{dcases}\\ &=\log\left[\frac{1+t'}{2} \right]+2\pi\max\{0,|\epsilon|-\epsilon_0\}. \end{aligned}$$*

*Proof.* Note that $$\begin{aligned} \log\left| \sqrt{1-t^2 {\mathrm{s}}^2(\theta + i\epsilon)} \right| % % % & = \frac{1}{2} \log|g_\epsilon(e^{2\pi i \theta})|, \end{aligned}$$ where $$g_\epsilon(z) = z^2 + \tfrac{t^2}{4} \left( z^4 e^{-4\pi\epsilon } - 2z^2 + e^{4\pi\epsilon}\right).$$ Solving $g(z) = 0$ gives the four roots $$\begin{aligned} \pm \sqrt{ \frac{\frac{t^2}{2}-1 \pm \sqrt{(1-\frac{t^2}{2})^2 - \frac{1}{4}t^4}}{\frac{1}{2} t^2 e^{-4\pi \epsilon}} } & = \pm \sqrt{ \frac{\frac{t^2}{2}-1 \pm \sqrt{1-t^2}}{\frac{1}{2} t^2 e^{-4\pi \epsilon}} } = \pm i \frac{1 \mp t'}{ t e^{-2\pi \epsilon} }. \end{aligned}$$ For $|\epsilon|<\epsilon_0$, the only roots of $g$ in ${\mathbb{D}}$ are $$r_\pm = \pm i \frac{1 - t'}{ t e^{-2\pi \epsilon} }.$$ Applying Jensen’s formula to $g$, we obtain $$\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2} \int_0^1 \log|g_\epsilon(e^{2\pi i \theta})| \, d\theta = \frac{1}{2} \left(\log|g_\epsilon(0)| - \log|r_{+}| - \log|r_{-}|\right) = \log\left(\frac t2\right) + 2\pi \epsilon - \log\left| \frac{1-t'}{te^{-2\pi \epsilon}} \right| \end{aligned}$$ which yields the desired result. The case $|\epsilon|>\epsilon_0$ is similar. ◻

Define $$\label{eq.scalarFactorCont} \tilde{\gamma}=\log\left[\frac{\lambda_{1}^{2}(1+\lambda_{2}')}{2}\right].$$ It follows immediately from the above lemma that the contribution of the scalar factors of the cocycle maps to the Lyapunov exponent is given by the following quantity: $$\label{eq:lyap_scalar_contribution} -\frac{1}{2}\int_{{\mathbb{T}}}\log|\rho_{3}(\theta)\rho_{2}\rho_{1}\rho_{0}|d\theta=-\frac{1}{2}\log\left[\frac{\lambda_{1}^{2}(1+\lambda_{2}')}{2}\right]=-\frac12\tilde\gamma.$$
*Proof of Theorem 12.* Denote $z=e^{it}$, in view of Lemma 13, it suffices to show that $$\label{lya1} L(2\Phi,S^{++}_{e^{it}}) = \max\left\{0,F(\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},t)\right\}.$$ We first complexify the phase by letting $\theta\mapsto\theta+i\epsilon$. Then, by the definition of Lyapunov exponent and [eq:defMz], $$\label{rela} L(2\Phi,S^{++}_{e^{it}}(\cdot+i\epsilon))=L(2\Phi,M_{e^{it}}(\cdot+i\epsilon))-\int_{{\mathbb{T}}}\log\lambda_{1}^{2}|w(\theta+i\epsilon)| \, d\theta.$$

On the other hand, by convexity, $\omega( 2 \Phi,M_{e^{it}}(\cdot+i\epsilon)) \leq 1$ for any $\epsilon\in {\mathbb{R}}$. Since $M_{e^{it}}(\cdot)\notin {\mathbb{SL}}(2,{\mathbb{C}})$, one cannot conclude $\omega( 2 \Phi,M_{e^{it}}(\cdot+i\epsilon)) \in {\mathbb{Z}}$ directly. Nevertheless, since $$S^{++}_{e^{it}}(\cdot)\in C^{\omega}({\mathbb{T}}, {\mathbb{SU}}(1,1)),$$ one may conclude that $\omega(2 \Phi,S^{++}_{e^{it}}(\cdot+i\epsilon))\in {\mathbb{Z}}$ for $|\epsilon|<\epsilon_{0}$ by Avila’s global theory . We distinguish two cases: **Case 1: $(2\Phi,S^{++}_{e^{it}})$ is subcritical.** Assume $(2\Phi,S^{++}_{e^{it}})$ is subcritical in the regime $|\epsilon|<\delta_0\leq \epsilon_{0}$. Let us note in passing that it is unknown whether the subcritical radius $\delta_0$ is exactly $\epsilon_{0}$. From the choice of $\delta_0$, we have $$\label{sub} L(2\Phi,S^{++}_{e^{it}}(\cdot+i\epsilon))=0 \quad \forall |\epsilon|<\delta_0.$$ **Case 2: $(2\Phi,S^{++}_{e^{it}})$ is supercritical or critical.** From [rela1] and the convexity of $L(2\Phi,M_{e^{it}}(\cdot+i\epsilon))$ it follows that $\omega(2\Phi,S^{++}_{e^{it}}(\cdot+i\epsilon))=1$ for $|\epsilon|<\epsilon_{0}$, and $\omega(2\Phi,M_{e^{it}}(\cdot+i\epsilon)) =1$ for all $\epsilon\in{\mathbb{R}}$. This implies that $$L(2\Phi,M_{e^{it}}(\cdot+i\epsilon))=\log\left[\frac{\lambda_{2}}2\left(2\lambda_{1}'|\cos t|+\sqrt{\lambda_{1}^{4}+4{\lambda_{1}'}^{2}\cos^{2}t}\right)\right]+2\pi\epsilon$$ for all $\epsilon\in{\mathbb{R}}$, where the case $\epsilon\leq 0$ follows by real-symmetry. As a consequence, by [eq:lyap_scalar_contribution] and [rela], we have $$\label{super}L(2\Phi,S^{++}_{e^{it}}(\cdot+i\epsilon)) =F(\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},t)+2\pi\epsilon.$$ Then [lya1] follows from [super] and [sub].

**Case 2: $(2\Phi,S^{++}_{e^{it}})$ is supercritical or critical.** From [rela1] and the convexity of $L(2\Phi,M_{e^{it}}(\cdot+i\epsilon))$ it follows that $\omega(2\Phi,S^{++}_{e^{it}}(\cdot+i\epsilon))=1$ for $|\epsilon|<\epsilon_{0}$, and $\omega(2\Phi,M_{e^{it}}(\cdot+i\epsilon)) =1$ for all $\epsilon\in{\mathbb{R}}$. This implies that $$L(2\Phi,M_{e^{it}}(\cdot+i\epsilon))=\log\left[\frac{\lambda_{2}}2\left(2\lambda_{1}'|\cos t|+\sqrt{\lambda_{1}^{4}+4{\lambda_{1}'}^{2}\cos^{2}t}\right)\right]+2\pi\epsilon$$ for all $\epsilon\in{\mathbb{R}}$, where the case $\epsilon\leq 0$ follows by real-symmetry. As a consequence, by [eq:lyap_scalar_contribution] and [rela], we have $$\label{super}L(2\Phi,S^{++}_{e^{it}}(\cdot+i\epsilon)) =F(\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},t)+2\pi\epsilon.$$ Then [lya1] follows from [super] and [sub]. By Corollary 3 and , $e^{it}\notin \Sigma_{\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},\Phi ,2}$ if and only if $(2\Phi,S^{++}_{e^{it}})$ is uniformly hyperbolic. Consequently, by Avila’s global theory , for any $e^{it}\in \Sigma_{\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},\Phi ,2}$, the corresponding cocycle $(2\Phi,S^{++}_{e^{it}})$ is either supercritical, critical, or subcritical. We thus only need to locate the spectral parameter $e^{it}$ which is supercritical or critical. Then $(b)$ and $(c)$ follows immediately from [super], and $(a)$ follows from $(b)$ and $(c)$, finally [lya1] follows from [super] and [sub]. ◻ If $\frac{\lambda_{1}^{2}\lambda_{2}'}{2\lambda_{1}'\lambda_{2}}\in(0,1)$ for given coupling constants $\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2}$ we define $$\label{eq:t_0} t_{0}=\arccos\left(\frac{\lambda_{1}^{2}\lambda_{2}'}{2\lambda_{1}'\lambda_{2}}\right).$$ A direct consequence of Theorem 12 is the following
**Corollary 15**. *Suppose that $e^{it}\in\Sigma_{\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},\Phi ,2}$. Then* - *$L(e^{it})>0$ for $t\in[0,t_{0})\cup(\pi-t_{0},\pi+t_{0})\cup(2\pi-t_{0},2\pi]$, and* - *$L(e^{it})=0$ for $t\in[t_{0},\pi-t_{0}]\cup[\pi+t_{0},2\pi-t_{0}]$.*

# Localization in the Supercritical Regime In this section, we prove that for *Diophantine* frequency $\Phi$ and *non-resonant* phase $\theta\in{\mathbb{T}}$, the generalized eigenfunctions of the mosaic UAMO decay exponentially for $L(z)>0$. This implies Anderson localization by a standard argument and thus proves Theorem 5. As discussed above, the mosaic UAMO can be transformed into a standard extended CMV matrix by a suitable gauge, so our main result also gives an interesting example (Anderson localization for fixed frequency) in the theory of OPUC. Moreover, we calculate the exact decay rate of the eigenfunctions. Localization

Localization We would like to utilize the evenness of the characteristic polynomial of the mosaic UAMO as a function of the phase $\theta$. However, inspecting Proposition 10 we find that the Verblunsky coefficients of the mosaic UAMO given in [eq:mosaicVerblunskies] do not possess the required symmetry property [eq.newReflectionProp]. Since we want to nevertheless utilize Proposition 10 we again leverage the gauge transformation in Theorem 1, yet, this time in the reverse direction: it turns out that by rotating each $\rho$ with even index by $\frac{\pi}{2}$ anti-clockwise reveals the hidden symmetry. As a consequence, we establish the evenness of suitable characteristic polynomials, a key ingredient in the proof of localization in , in our proof of localization for (GE)CMV matrices.

Rotating the $\rho$’s with even index as prescribed above, we introduce the following “complexified twin” of the mosaic UAMO model: $$\label{eq.blockDef3} \begin{alignedat}{4} \alpha_{4n-1}&=\lambda_{2}\sin2\pi(\theta+2n\Phi),&\qquad\alpha_{4n+1}&=0,&\qquad\alpha_{4n}&=\alpha_{4n+2}=\lambda_{1}',\\ \rho_{4n-1}&=\lambda_{2}\cos2\pi(\theta+2n\Phi)-i\lambda_{2}',&\qquad\rho_{4n+1}&=-i,&\qquad\rho_{4n}&=\rho_{4n+2}=i\lambda_{1}. \end{alignedat}$$ We denote the corresponding GECMV matrix by $\mathcal{E}^{i}$ and similarly its building blocks by $\mathcal{L}^{i}$ and $\mathcal{M}^{i}$ such that $\mathcal E^i=\mathcal L^i\mathcal M^i$. Comparing [eq:mosaicVerblunskies] with [eq.blockDef3], we emphasize that the tiny change $\rho_{2n}\mapsto i\rho_{2n}$ paves the way for applying the reflection symmetry argument introduced in Section [sec:reflection]: One easily verifies that after the coordinate shift $\theta\mapsto\theta+\frac14$ the coefficients [eq.blockDef3] satisfy [eq.newReflectionProp] for $c=-1/2$, since the only non-constant terms have index $4n-1$ for which indeed $$\label{eq:alpha_i_sym} \alpha_{4n-1}(\theta+\tfrac14)=\lambda_{2}\cos 2\pi(2n\Phi+\theta)=\lambda_{2}\cos 2\pi(-2n\Phi-\theta)=\alpha_{-4n-1}(-\theta+\tfrac14),$$ and $$\label{eq:rho_i_sym} \rho_{4n-1}(\theta+\tfrac14)=\lambda_{2}\sin2\pi(2n\Phi+\theta)+i\lambda_{2}'=-\lambda_{2}\sin2\pi(-2n\Phi-\theta)+i\lambda_{2}'=-\overline{\rho_{-4n-1}(-\theta+\tfrac14)}.$$ We will also need the associated “standard" extended CMV matrix $\tilde{\mathcal{E}}=\tilde{\mathcal{E}}(\alpha,|\rho|)$ with every complex $\rho$ replaced by its absolute value, and we shall write $\tilde{\mathcal{E}}=\tilde{\mathcal{L}}\tilde{\mathcal{M}}$. The role of $\tilde{\mathcal{E}}$ is to connect existing theory for extended CMV matrices to our setting. The following observation is an elementary consequence of Theorem 1:
**Proposition 16**. *Let $\mathcal{E}, \mathcal{E}^{i}$ be the GECMV matrices with coefficients [eq:mosaicVerblunskies] and [eq.blockDef3], respectively, and let $\tilde{\mathcal{E}}$ be the associated extended CMV matrix. Then* 1. *$\mathcal{E}$, $\mathcal{E}^{i}$ and $\tilde{\mathcal{E}}$ are mutually unitarily equivalent.* 2. *The Lyapunov exponents of the cocycles corresponding to $\mathcal{E}$, $\mathcal{E}^{i}$ and $\tilde{\mathcal{E}}$ are identical.* 3. *The spectra and spectral measures of $\mathcal{E}$, $\mathcal{E}^{i}$ and $\tilde{\mathcal{E}}$ are identical.* 4. *The dynamics of the solutions to the eigenvalue equations of $\mathcal{E}$, $\mathcal{E}^{i}$ and $\tilde{\mathcal{E}}$ are identical.*
Recall the definition of Diophantine numbers in [eq:diophsigmagamma] and [eq:dioph].

**Definition 17** ($\Phi$-resonant). Given $\Phi\in {\mathrm{DC}}(\kappa,\tau)$, $\kappa>0$, $\tau>1$, $\theta\in{\mathbb{T}}$ is called *resonant* with respect to $\Phi$ if $$\left|\sin2\pi\left( \theta+ n\Phi \right)\right|<\exp(-|n|^{\frac{1}{2\tau}})$$ holds for infinitely many $n\in{\mathbb{Z}}$. Otherwise, $\theta$ is called *non-resonant* with respect to $\Phi$.
It is known that the collection of all Diophantine frequencies has full Lebesgue measure in ${\mathbb{T}}$, and the set of $\Phi$-resonant phases is a dense $G_{\delta}$-subset with zero Lebesgue measure in ${\mathbb{T}}$ (see ). Note that $\mathcal{E},\mathcal{E}^{i}$ and $\tilde{\mathcal{E}}$ depend on $\theta$ for fixed $\Phi$. We will use $X(\theta),X\in\{\mathcal{E},\mathcal{E}^{i},\tilde{\mathcal{E}}\}$ to make such dependence explicit, yet, we sometimes suppress them from the notations to make things look concise. The main purpose of this subsection is to prove the following theorem:
**Theorem 18**. *Let $\tilde{\mathcal{E}}(\theta)$ be the associated extended CMV matrix of [eq.blockDef3], and assume that $\Phi\in {\mathrm{DC}}$ is fixed and $L(z)>0$. If $\theta$ is *non-resonant* with respect to $\Phi$, then $\tilde{\mathcal{E}}(\theta)$ displays Anderson localization.*

Once we have this, Theorem [thm:mobs] (b) follows as a consequence of Proposition 16 (4). To prove Theorem 18, it suffices to show that every generalized eigenfunction of $\tilde{\mathcal{E}}$ decays exponentially.
**Definition 19**. We say that a nonzero sequence $\Psi:{\mathbb{Z}}\to{\mathbb{C}}$ is a *generalized eigenfunction* of the extended CMV matrix $\tilde{\mathcal{E}}$ with corresponding generalized eigenvalue $z\in{\mathbb{C}}$ if $$\tilde{\mathcal{E}}\Psi=z\Psi$$ and there exist constants $M,N$ such that $|\Psi_{n}|\leq M(1+|n|)^{N}$, i.e., $\Psi$ is polynomially bounded.

Schnol’s theorem asserts that the generalized eigenvalues sit in the spectrum and that they comprise *spectrally* almost every $z$ in the spectrum. To formulate this precisely, one needs the following notion. It is well-known and not hard to check that for any $k$, $\{\delta_{2k},\delta_{2k+1}\}$ is a cyclic set for any CMV matrix with nonvanishing $\rho$’s. The reader may find a detailed proof for the CMV case in , or in the more general matrix-valued version in . Thus, the spectral measure $\mu_{\tilde{{\mathcal{E}}}}^{\mathrm{univ}}$ given by $$\int f(z) \, d\mu_{\tilde{{\mathcal{E}}}}^{\mathrm{univ}}(z) = \langle \delta_0, f(\tilde{{\mathcal{E}}}) \delta_0 \rangle + \langle \delta_1, f(\tilde{{\mathcal{E}}}) \delta_1 \rangle$$ serves as a universal spectral measure of $\mathcal{E}$ in the sense that every other spectral measure of $\tilde{{\mathcal{E}}}$ is absolutely continuous with respect to $\mu_{\tilde{{\mathcal{E}}}}^{\mathrm{univ}}$. Then one has that
**Theorem 20** (Schnol’s Theorem). *Let $\tilde{{\mathcal{E}}}$ be an extended CMV matrix, $\mathcal{G}$ the set of its generalized eigenvalues, and $\sigma(\tilde{\mathcal{E}})$ its spectrum. Then we have the following:* - *$\mathcal{G}\subset\sigma(\tilde{\mathcal{E}})$,* - *$\mu_{\tilde{{\mathcal{E}}}}^{\mathrm{univ}}(\sigma(\tilde{\mathcal{E}})\setminus\mathcal{G})=0$,* - *$\overline{\mathcal{G}}=\sigma(\tilde{\mathcal{E}})$.*

To deduce the desired localization statements, the key is to prove the exponential decay of the Green’s functions. Let us first introduce some necessary notations. Let $\Lambda=[a,b]\subset{\mathbb{Z}}$ be a finite interval and $\beta_{1},\beta_{2}\in\partial{\mathbb{D}}\cup\{\bullet\}$. Given $\{\alpha_{n}\}\subset{\mathbb{D}}$, define $\{\tilde{\alpha}_{n}\}\subset\overline{{\mathbb{D}}}$ as follows: $$\label{eq.newVerblunsky} \tilde{\alpha}_{j}=\begin{cases} \beta_{1}& j=a-1,\\ \alpha_{j}& j\neq a-1,b,\\ \beta_{2}& j=b. \end{cases}$$ Let $\mathcal{E}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}$ be the GECMV matrix with Verblunsky coefficients $\{\tilde{\alpha}_{n},\rho_{n}\}$ and let $\chi_{\Lambda}$ be the projection onto $\Lambda$. Define $\mathcal{E}_{\Lambda}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}=\chi_{\Lambda}\mathcal{E}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}\chi^{*}_{\Lambda}$. One can verify that $\mathcal{E}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{\Lambda}$ is unitary when $\beta_{1},\beta_{2}\in\partial{\mathbb{D}}$. We will also use $\mathcal{E}_{\Lambda}^{\bullet,\beta_{2}}=\mathcal{E}_{\Lambda}^{\alpha_{a-1},\beta_{2}}$ and $\mathcal{E}^{\beta_{1},\bullet}_{\Lambda}=\mathcal{E}_{\Lambda}^{\beta_{1},\alpha_{b}}$ to denote the finite restrictions where the boundary conditions are chosen in $\partial{\mathbb{D}}$ on one side of $\Lambda$ and open on the other. The finite unitary restrictions $\mathcal{L}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{\Lambda}$ and $\mathcal{M}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{\Lambda}$ are defined in the same way.

Let $\mathcal{E}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}$ be the GECMV matrix with Verblunsky coefficients $\{\tilde{\alpha}_{n},\rho_{n}\}$ and let $\chi_{\Lambda}$ be the projection onto $\Lambda$. Define $\mathcal{E}_{\Lambda}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}=\chi_{\Lambda}\mathcal{E}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}\chi^{*}_{\Lambda}$. One can verify that $\mathcal{E}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{\Lambda}$ is unitary when $\beta_{1},\beta_{2}\in\partial{\mathbb{D}}$. We will also use $\mathcal{E}_{\Lambda}^{\bullet,\beta_{2}}=\mathcal{E}_{\Lambda}^{\alpha_{a-1},\beta_{2}}$ and $\mathcal{E}^{\beta_{1},\bullet}_{\Lambda}=\mathcal{E}_{\Lambda}^{\beta_{1},\alpha_{b}}$ to denote the finite restrictions where the boundary conditions are chosen in $\partial{\mathbb{D}}$ on one side of $\Lambda$ and open on the other. The finite unitary restrictions $\mathcal{L}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{\Lambda}$ and $\mathcal{M}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{\Lambda}$ are defined in the same way. Let $$\rho_\Lambda=\prod_{j\in\Lambda}\rho_{j},$$ and define $$\label{eq.Polynomial} P^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,\Lambda}=|\rho_\Lambda|^{-1}\det(z\mathbbm{1}-(\mathcal{E}^i)^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{\Lambda})$$ for the GECMV matrix $\mathcal E^i$. For the case $a>b$, we just take $P^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,[a,b]}=1$. Analogously, define $$\label{eq.Polynomial1} \tilde{P}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,\Lambda}=|\rho_\Lambda|^{-1}\det(z\mathbbm{1}-\tilde{\mathcal{E}}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{\Lambda})$$ for the CMV matrix $\mathcal E$. Then we have the following invariance property:
**Lemma 21**. *Let $\mathcal{E}^{i},\tilde{\mathcal{E}},P^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,\Lambda}, \tilde{P}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,\Lambda}$ be as above. Then $$P^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,\Lambda}=\tilde{P}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,\Lambda}.$$*

*Proof.* This follows from two observations: (1) By Theorem 1, there exists a unitary diagonal gauge transformation $D$ such that $(\mathcal{E}^{i})^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}=D\tilde{\mathcal{E}}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}D^{*}$. (2) $\chi_\Lambda$ and $D$ are both diagonal matrices, such that $\chi_\Lambda D=D\chi_\Lambda=(\chi_\Lambda D\chi_\Lambda)\chi_\Lambda=:D_\Lambda \chi_\Lambda$. Therefore, $$\begin{aligned} \det(z\mathbbm{1}-(\mathcal{E}^{i})^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{\Lambda}) =\det \chi_{\Lambda}D(z\mathbbm{1}-\tilde{\mathcal{E}}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}})D^{*}\chi^{*}_{\Lambda} =\det D_{\Lambda}(z\mathbbm{1}-\tilde{\mathcal{E}}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{\Lambda})D^{*}_{\Lambda}. \end{aligned}$$ Multiplying with $|\rho_\Lambda|^{-1}$ on both sides concludes the proof . ◻

We emphasize that this equivalence is crucial since it connects the current setting of GECMV matrices to the existing theory for extended CMV matrices in that it allows us to transfer statements about $\tilde P^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,\Lambda}$ to $P^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,\Lambda}$. More concretely, our main application of Lemma 21 will be to write down the exact relations [eq.GreenToTransfer] and [eq.GreentoTransfer1] below for GECMV matrices. This is important, since $\mathcal E^i$ possesses a reflection symmetry which will allow us to conclude the evenness of $\det(z\mathbbm{1}-(\mathcal{E}^{i})^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{[1,4k-2]})(\theta)$. We henceforth do not distinguish explicitly [eq.Polynomial] from [eq.Polynomial1], and in slight abuse of notation just write $P^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,\Lambda}$. Recalling $\tilde{\gamma}$ given in [eq.scalarFactorCont], we need the following estimates:
**Lemma 22**. *For any $\eta>0$, there exists $N>0$ such that for any $n>N$ $$e^{n(\tilde{\gamma}/4-\eta)}\leq\prod_{j=0}^{n-1}|\rho_{j}|\leq e^{n(\tilde{\gamma}/4+\eta)}.$$*

*Proof.* Since $\rho_{4j-1}(\theta)=\lambda_{2}\cos2\pi(\theta+2j\Phi)-i\lambda_{2}'$ and $\rho_{2j}=\lambda_{1},\rho_{4j+1}=-i$ by [eq:mosaicVerblunskies], and $\theta\to\theta+2\Phi$ is ergodic in ${\mathbb{T}}$, by the Ergodic Theorem and [eq:lyap_scalar_contribution], $$\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}\frac{1}{n}\log\left[\prod_{j=1}^{n}|\rho_{4j-1}(\theta)\rho_{4j-2}\rho_{4j-3}\rho_{4j-4}|\right]=\int_{{\mathbb{T}}}\log|\rho_{3}(\theta)\rho_{2}\rho_{1}\rho_{0}|d\theta=\tilde{\gamma}.$$ For any $n>0$, let $l$ be the integer such that $n=4l+r$ with $0\leq r\leq 3.$ Then $$\prod_{j=0}^{n-1}|\rho_{j}|=\begin{dcases} \prod_{k=1}^{l}|\rho_{4k-1}(\theta)\rho_{4k-2}\rho_{4k-3}\rho_{4k-4}| & r=0,\\ \prod_{i=0}^{r-1}|\rho_{4l+i}|\prod_{k=1}^{l}|\rho_{4k-1}(\theta)\rho_{4k-2}\rho_{4k-3}\rho_{4k-4}| & r=1,2,3. \end{dcases}$$ Therefore, we have $$\frac{1}{n}\left|\log\prod_{j=0}^{n-1}|\rho_{j}|-\log\prod_{k=1}^{l}|\rho_{4k-1}(\theta)\rho_{4k-2}\rho_{4k-3}\rho_{4k-4}|\right|\leq \frac{\log|\rho_{2}\rho_{1}\rho_{0}|}{n}=\frac{|\log\lambda_{1}^{2}|}{n}$$ Thus for any $\eta>0$, there exists $N>0$ such that for any $n>N$ $$\left|\frac{1}{n}\log\prod_{j=0}^{n-1}|\rho_{j}|-\frac{\tilde{\gamma}}{4}\right|\leq\eta.$$ ◻

Consider the equation $(z\mathbbm{1}-\tilde{\mathcal{E}})\Psi^{z}=0$. Since $\tilde{\mathcal{E}}=\tilde{\mathcal{L}}\tilde{\mathcal{M}}$, it follows equivalently that $(z\tilde{\mathcal{L}}^{*}-\tilde{\mathcal{M}})\Psi^{z}=0$. Define the finite-volume *Green’s function* as $$\label{eq.GreenFunction} \tilde{G}_{z,\Lambda}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}:=\left(z(\tilde{\mathcal{L}}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{\Lambda})^{*}-\tilde{\mathcal{M}}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{\Lambda}\right)^{-1},$$ and denote its matrix elements for $x,y\in\Lambda$ by $\tilde{G}_{z,\Lambda}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}(x,y):=\langle \delta_{x},\tilde{G}_{z,\Lambda}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}\delta_{y}\rangle$. Then, by we have for $a21 we have that $$\label{eq.GreenToTransfer} \begin{bmatrix}P^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,[a,b]}&P^{-\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,[a,b]}\\P^{\beta_{1},-\beta_{2}}_{z,[a,b]}&P^{-\beta_{1},-\beta_{2}}_{z,[a,b]}\end{bmatrix}= \begin{bmatrix}z&-\overline{\beta_{2}}\\z&\overline{\beta_{2}}\end{bmatrix}\left(\frac{1}{|\rho_{b}|}\prod_{j=a}^{b-1}\tilde{S}_{j,z}\right)\begin{bmatrix}1&1\\\beta_{1}&-\beta_{1}\end{bmatrix}$$ and $$\label{eq.GreentoTransfer1} \begin{bmatrix}P^{\beta,\bullet}_{z,\Lambda}\\P^{\bullet,\beta}_{z,\Lambda}\end{bmatrix}=\prod_{j=a}^{b}\tilde{S}_{j,z}\begin{bmatrix}1\\\overline{\beta}\end{bmatrix}.$$ It follows that $$\label{eq.PolynomialUpperBound} |P^{\beta_{1},\bullet}_{z,[a,x-1]}|\leq \sqrt{2}\:\Bigg\Vert \prod_{j=a}^{x-1}\tilde{S}_{j,z}\Bigg\Vert, \qquad |P^{\bullet,\beta_{2}}_{z,[y+1,b]}|\leq\sqrt{2}\:\Bigg\Vert\prod_{j=y+1}^{b}\tilde{S}_{j,z}\Bigg\Vert.$$

We prove this lemma at the end of this section. In the following, we will take $\gamma\equiv L(z)/2$ for simplicity, and we will fix $z$ and $\theta$ and suppress them from the notation. Assuming that Lemma 24 holds, we can prove Theorem 18.
*Proof of Theorem 18.* By Schnol’s theorem (Theorem 20), it is enough to prove that any generalized eigenfunction decays exponentially. For $|y|>k_{0}$, since $y$ is $(\gamma-\epsilon,\bar k)-$regular by Lemma 24, we have $$|\tilde{G}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,[n_{1},n_{2}]}(y,n_{i})|[eq.solGreen]: $$\begin{aligned} |\Psi^{z}(y)|&\leq 2e^{-(\gamma-\epsilon)(y-n_{1})}\max\{|\Psi^{z}(n_{1})|,|\Psi^{z}(n_{1}+1)|\} \\ &\qquad + 2e^{-(\gamma-\epsilon)(n_{2}-y)}\max\{|\Psi^{z}(n_{2})|,|\Psi^{z}(n_{2}-1)|\}\\ &\leq 2\left(e^{-(\gamma-\epsilon)(y-n_{1})}M(1+|n_{1}|)^{N}+e^{-(\gamma-\epsilon)(n_{1}-y)}M(1+|n_{2}|^{N})\right).

*Proof of Theorem 18.* By Schnol’s theorem (Theorem 20), it is enough to prove that any generalized eigenfunction decays exponentially. For $|y|>k_{0}$, since $y$ is $(\gamma-\epsilon,\bar k)-$regular by Lemma 24, we have $$|\tilde{G}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,[n_{1},n_{2}]}(y,n_{i})|[eq.solGreen]: $$\begin{aligned} |\Psi^{z}(y)|&\leq 2e^{-(\gamma-\epsilon)(y-n_{1})}\max\{|\Psi^{z}(n_{1})|,|\Psi^{z}(n_{1}+1)|\} \\ &\qquad + 2e^{-(\gamma-\epsilon)(n_{2}-y)}\max\{|\Psi^{z}(n_{2})|,|\Psi^{z}(n_{2}-1)|\}\\ &\leq 2\left(e^{-(\gamma-\epsilon)(y-n_{1})}M(1+|n_{1}|)^{N}+e^{-(\gamma-\epsilon)(n_{1}-y)}M(1+|n_{2}|^{N})\right). \end{aligned}$$ Since $|n_{i}|\leq |n_{i}-y|+|y|$ for $i=1,2$, we have $$(1+|n_{i}|^{N})\leq 2^{N}\max\{|y|^{N},|n_{i}-y|^{N}\},$$ such that in both cases we have the exponential decay estimate $$|\Psi^{z}(y)|\leq e^{-(\gamma-\epsilon)\frac{5|y|}{14\times16}}.$$ From this the result follows. ◻ It remains to to prove Lemma 24, which we do in a sequence of steps. More concretely, we need to establish the exponential upper bound on the absolute value of the Green’s function $\tilde{G}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,[a,b]}$ in the definition of regularity (Definition 23). To this end, we consult [eq.GreenToPolynomial] and bound the numerator from above and the denominator from below. Define $\tilde{S}^{++}_{n,z}$ as the four-step quasi-periodic cocycle of $\tilde{S}_{n,z}$ in the same fashion as in [eq.combinedSzego]. It is readily verified that for $z\in\partial{\mathbb{D}}$, we have $L(2\Phi,\tilde{S}^{++}_{z})=L(2\Phi,S^{++}_{z})=2L(z)$, where $L(z)$ is the Lyapunov exponent given in Theorem 12.
**Lemma 25**. *For any $\epsilon>0$, $z\in\partial{\mathbb{D}}$, there exists $k_{1}=k_{1}(\epsilon,z)$ such that $$\left|P^{\beta_{1},\bullet}_{z,[a,b]}\right|,\:\left|P^{\bullet,\beta_{2}}_{z,[a,b]}\right|< e^{(\gamma+\epsilon)(b-a+1)}$$ if $b-a+1>k_{1}$.*

*Proof.* By [eq:twoblockAzdef], [eq.ConjugatedTransferMatrix] and [eq.combinedSzego], we have $$L(z)=\lim_{k\to\infty}\frac{1}{2k}\int_{{\mathbb{T}}}\log\Bigg\Vert\prod_{j=k-1}^{0}A^{+}_{z}(\theta+2j\Phi)\Bigg\Vert d\theta=\lim_{k\to\infty}\frac{1}{2k}\int_{{\mathbb{T}}}\log\Bigg\Vert\prod_{j=k-1}^{0}S_{z}^{++}(\theta+2j\Phi)\Bigg\Vert d\theta.$$ Therefore $$L(z)=\lim\limits_{k\to\infty}\frac{1}{2k}\int_{{\mathbb{T}}}\log\Bigg\Vert\prod_{j=k-1}^{0}\tilde{S}^{++}_{z}(\theta+2j\Phi)\Bigg\Vert d\theta.$$ Since $\tilde{S}^{++}_{z}$ are four combined steps of $\tilde{S}_{j,z}$ this implies that $\lim_{k\to\infty}k^{-1}\int_{{\mathbb{T}}}\log\Vert \prod_{j=k-1}^{0}\tilde{S}_{j,z}(\theta)\Vert d\theta=L(z)/2=\gamma.$ Then the statement follows from Furman’s well-known result and [eq.PolynomialUpperBound]. ◻

Recall that $P^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,\Lambda}$ in [eq.Polynomial] and [eq.Polynomial1] depends on the phase parameter $\theta$. In the following, we will write $P^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,\Lambda}(\theta)$ to make this dependence explicit. Now let us give the lower bound on the denominator in [eq.GreenToPolynomial] by following the idea of . To facilitate the proof, we restrict to the concrete interval $[1,4k-2]$ which is the only interval we shall require:
**Lemma 26**. *For any $\epsilon>0$, $z\in\partial{\mathbb{D}}$, there exists $k_{2}=k_{2}(\epsilon,z)> 0$ such that $$\frac{1}{4k-2}\int_{{\mathbb{T}}}\log|P^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,[1,4k-2]}(\theta)|d\theta\geq \gamma-\epsilon$$ for any $4k-2>k_{2}$.*

*Proof.* Let $D(\theta)=|\rho_{3}\rho_{2}\rho_{1}\rho_{0}|\tilde{S}_{3,z}\tilde{S}_{2,z}\tilde{S}_{1,z}\tilde{S}_{0,z}$ with $\tilde{S}_{n,z}$ given by [eq.Zego]. Direct computation gives $$D(\theta)=z^{2}\begin{bmatrix} z^{2}+\lambda_{1}'^{2}+\lambda_{1}'\lambda_{2}s(\theta')(z+z^{-1})&-\lambda_{1}'(z+z^{-1})-\lambda_{2}s(\theta')(\lambda_{1}'^{2}+z^{-2})\\ -\lambda_{1}'(z+z^{-1})-\lambda_{2}s(\theta')(\lambda_{1}'^{2}+z^{2})&\lambda_{1}'^{2}+z^{-2}+\lambda_{1}'\lambda_{2}s(\theta)(z+z^{-1}) \end{bmatrix},$$ where we recall from [eq:cstwopi] the notation $s(\theta)=\sin2\pi(\theta)$ and we set $\theta'=\theta+2\Phi$. Writing $z=e^{it}$ and $s(\theta')=(e^{2\pi i\theta'}-e^{-2\pi i\theta'})/(2i)=(w-w^{-1})/(2i)$, where $w=e^{2\pi i\theta'}$, then $D(\theta)$ can be written as $$\begin{aligned} D(\theta)&=w^{-1}e^{2it}\begin{bmatrix} (\lambda_{1}'^{2}+z^{2})w+2\lambda_{1}'\lambda_{2}\cos(t) \frac{w^{2}-1}{2i}&-2\lambda_{1}'w\cos(t)-\lambda_{2}(\lambda_{1}'^{2}+z^{-2}) \frac{w^{2}-1}{2i})\\ -2\lambda_{1}'w\cos(t)-\lambda_{2}(\lambda_{1}'^{2}+z^{2})\frac{w^{2}-1}{2i}&(\lambda_{1}'^{2}+z^{-2})w+2\lambda_{1}'\lambda_{2}\cos(t)\frac{w^{2}-1}{2i} \end{bmatrix}\\ &=:w^{-1}e^{2it}\hat{D}(w). \end{aligned}$$ Let $\tilde{\gamma}$ be given by [eq.scalarFactorCont] and let $$V=\begin{bmatrix}1&0\\0&0\end{bmatrix},\quad B_{1}=\begin{bmatrix}1&1\\\beta_{1}&-\beta_{1}\end{bmatrix},\quad B_{2}=\begin{bmatrix}z&-\overline{\beta_{2}}\\z&\overline{\beta_{2}}\end{bmatrix}.$$ Then, by [eq.GreenToTransfer], $$\label{eq.midCal} \begin{aligned} \int_{{\mathbb{T}}}\log|P^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,[1,4k-2]}(\theta)|d\theta+(k-1)\tilde{\gamma} &=\int_{{\mathbb{T}}}\log\Bigg\Vert VB_{2}\tilde{S}_{4k-3,z}\prod_{j=0}^{k-2}D(\theta+j2\Phi)\tilde{S}_{0,z}^{-1}B_{1}V\Bigg\Vert d\theta \\ &=\int_{\partial{\mathbb{D}}}\log\Bigg\Vert V B_{2}\tilde{S}_{4k-3,z} \prod_{j=0}^{k-2}w^{-1}e^{2it}\hat{D}(we^{2ij2\Phi})\tilde{S}_{0,z}^{-1}B_{1}V\Bigg\Vert dw\\ &\geq\log\Bigg\Vert VB_{2}\tilde{S}_{4k-3,z}\prod_{j=0}^{k-2}\hat{D}(0)\tilde{S}^{-1}_{0,z}B_{1}V\Bigg\Vert. \end{aligned}$$ The last inequality is due to subharmonicity. By [eq.blockDef3], $$\tilde{S}_{4k-3,z}=i\begin{bmatrix}z&0\\0&1\end{bmatrix},\qquad\tilde{S}_{0,z}=\frac{1}{i\lambda_{1}}\begin{bmatrix}z&-\lambda_{1}'\\-\lambda_{1}'z&1\end{bmatrix},$$ and $$\begin{aligned}\hat{D}(0)&=\frac{\lambda_{2}}{2i}\begin{bmatrix} -2\lambda_{1}'\cos(t)&\lambda_{1}'^{2}+z^{-2}\\ \lambda_{1}'^{2}+z^{2}&-2\lambda_{1}'\cos(t) \end{bmatrix} =\frac{\lambda_{2}}{2i}Q^{-1}\begin{bmatrix}\lambda_+&0\\0&\lambda_-\end{bmatrix}Q \end{aligned}$$ where $Q$ is the normalized diagonalization matrix ($\det Q=1$), and $$\lambda_{\pm}=2\lambda_{1}'\cos t\pm\sqrt{\lambda_{1}^{2}+4\lambda_{1}'^{2}\cos^{2}t}.$$ Direct computations give the right side of [eq.midCal] as a linear combination of the log of $(\frac{\lambda_{2}}{2}\lambda_{\pm})^{k-1}$ with non-zero constant coefficients (independent of $k$). Thus, for any $\epsilon>0$ and $4k-2>k_{2}(\epsilon,z)$ large enough, we have $$\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{4k-2}\int_{{\mathbb{T}}}\log|P_{z,[1,4k-2]}(\theta)|d\theta&\geq\frac{1}{4}\left(\log\frac{\lambda_{2}(2\lambda_{1}'|\cos t|+\sqrt{\lambda_{1}^{2}+4\lambda_{1}'^{2}\cos^{2}t})}{2}-\tilde{\gamma}\right)-\epsilon\\ &=\gamma-\epsilon. \end{aligned}$$ ◻

*Proof.* First note that $\Gamma^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,[1,4k-2]}(\theta)$ is a polynomial in $\sin2\pi\theta$ and $\cos2\pi\theta$ of degree at most $k$. This is a direct consequence of [eq.Polynomial1], Lemma 21, [eq.GreenToTransfer] and our specific model [eq.blockDef3]. Next, we show that $\Gamma_{z,[1,4k-2]}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}(\theta+\frac{1}{4}-(k-1)\Phi)$ is an even function of $\theta$: Recall the reflection symmetry of the $\alpha_j$ and $\rho_j$ established in [eq:alpha_i_sym] and [eq:rho_i_sym], respectively. Then, evenness in $\theta$ follows from applying Proposition 10 to $\Gamma_{z,[1,4k-2]}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}(\theta+\frac{1}{4}-(k-1)\Phi)$. The change of variable $\theta\mapsto\theta+(k-1)\Phi$ concludes the proof. ◻ By Lemma 27, there exists a polynomial $Q_{k}$ of degree $k$ such that $\Gamma^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,[1,4k-2]}(\theta+\frac{1}{4})=Q_{k}(\cos2\pi(\theta+(k-1)\Phi))$. For any positive integer $k$ and $r>0$, define $$A_{k}^{r}=\{\theta\in{\mathbb{T}}:|Q_{k}(\cos2\pi\theta)|\leq e^{kr}\}.$$ Define $$\label{eq.newExponent} \gamma'=\gamma+\tilde{\gamma}/4.$$ Then, similar to , the following holds:

**Lemma 28**. *Assume that $y$ is $(\gamma-\epsilon,4k-2)$-singular for some $k\in {\mathbb{Z}}$ and $\epsilon>0$. Then for each $j\in{\mathbb{Z}}$ with $$y-\left\lfloor\frac{2}{4}(4k-2)\right\rfloor+(k-1)\leq 2j\leq y+\left\lfloor\frac{1}{4}(4k-2)\right\rfloor+(k-1) ,$$ we have $\theta+ 2j\Phi\in A^{4\gamma'-\frac{\epsilon}{8}}_{k}$, where $\gamma'$ is given by [eq.newExponent], provided $4k-2>k_{3}(\gamma,\frac{\epsilon}{48})$ is sufficiently large.*

*Proof.* Let us take $k_{3}=\max\{k_{0},k_{1},k_{2},N\}$ with $N, k_0$, $k_1$, $k_2$ from Lemma 22, Lemma 24, Lemma 25 and Lemma 26, respectively. Then, by Lemma 25, for any $\epsilon'>0$, $b-a+1>k_{3}$ $$\label{eq.PupperB} \left|P^{\beta_{1},\bullet}_{z,[a,b]}\right|,\left|P^{\bullet,\beta_{2}}_{z,[a,b]}\right|< e^{|b-a+1|(\gamma+\epsilon')}.$$ Since $y$ is $(\gamma-\epsilon,4k-2)$-singular, then without loss of generality, for any $n_{1}e^{-|y-n_{1}|(\gamma-\epsilon)}.$$ Suppose that there exists some $j_0$ with $$y-\left\lfloor\frac{2}{4}(4k-2)\right\rfloor+(k-1)\leq 2j_{0}\leq y+\left\lfloor\frac{1}{4}(4k-2)\right\rfloor+(k-1)$$ such that $\theta+2j_{0}\Phi\notin A_{k}^{4\gamma'-\frac{\epsilon}{8}}$, that is, $|Q_{k}(\cos 2\pi(\theta+2j_{0}\Phi))|>e^{k(4\gamma'-\frac{\epsilon}{8})}$. Let $\tilde{\theta}=\theta+(j_{0}-(k-1))\Phi$. Then $|\Gamma^{\beta_{2},\beta_{2}}_{z,[1,4k-2]}(\tilde{\theta})|>e^{k(4\gamma'-\frac{\epsilon}{8})}$ by Lemma 27. By [eq.GreenToPolynomial] and [eq.PupperB], we conclude that $$|\tilde{G}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,[n_{1},n_{2}]}(y,n_{1})|<|\rho_{y}|^{-1}\left(\prod_{j=n_{1}}^{n_{2}}|\rho_{j}|\right)e^{(\gamma+\epsilon')(n_{2}-y)}e^{-k(4\gamma'-\frac{\epsilon}{8})}.$$ By Lemma 22, if $4k-2>N$, we have $$\prod_{j=n_{1},j\neq y}^{n_{2}}|\rho_{j}|\leq e^{(n_{2}-n_{1})(\tilde{\gamma}/4+\eta)}.$$ Putting the above inequalities together yields $$|\tilde{G}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,[n_{1},n_{2}]}(y,n_{1})|

*Proof.* Let us take $k_{3}=\max\{k_{0},k_{1},k_{2},N\}$ with $N, k_0$, $k_1$, $k_2$ from Lemma 22, Lemma 24, Lemma 25 and Lemma 26, respectively. Then, by Lemma 25, for any $\epsilon'>0$, $b-a+1>k_{3}$ $$\label{eq.PupperB} \left|P^{\beta_{1},\bullet}_{z,[a,b]}\right|,\left|P^{\bullet,\beta_{2}}_{z,[a,b]}\right|< e^{|b-a+1|(\gamma+\epsilon')}.$$ Since $y$ is $(\gamma-\epsilon,4k-2)$-singular, then without loss of generality, for any $n_{1}e^{-|y-n_{1}|(\gamma-\epsilon)}.$$ Suppose that there exists some $j_0$ with $$y-\left\lfloor\frac{2}{4}(4k-2)\right\rfloor+(k-1)\leq 2j_{0}\leq y+\left\lfloor\frac{1}{4}(4k-2)\right\rfloor+(k-1)$$ such that $\theta+2j_{0}\Phi\notin A_{k}^{4\gamma'-\frac{\epsilon}{8}}$, that is, $|Q_{k}(\cos 2\pi(\theta+2j_{0}\Phi))|>e^{k(4\gamma'-\frac{\epsilon}{8})}$. Let $\tilde{\theta}=\theta+(j_{0}-(k-1))\Phi$. Then $|\Gamma^{\beta_{2},\beta_{2}}_{z,[1,4k-2]}(\tilde{\theta})|>e^{k(4\gamma'-\frac{\epsilon}{8})}$ by Lemma 27. By [eq.GreenToPolynomial] and [eq.PupperB], we conclude that $$|\tilde{G}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,[n_{1},n_{2}]}(y,n_{1})|<|\rho_{y}|^{-1}\left(\prod_{j=n_{1}}^{n_{2}}|\rho_{j}|\right)e^{(\gamma+\epsilon')(n_{2}-y)}e^{-k(4\gamma'-\frac{\epsilon}{8})}.$$ By Lemma 22, if $4k-2>N$, we have $$\prod_{j=n_{1},j\neq y}^{n_{2}}|\rho_{j}|\leq e^{(n_{2}-n_{1})(\tilde{\gamma}/4+\eta)}.$$ Putting the above inequalities together yields $$|\tilde{G}^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,[n_{1},n_{2}]}(y,n_{1})| We can write a polynomial $Q_k(x)$ of degree $k$ in the following Lagrange interpolation form $$\label{langrange} Q_{k}(x)=\sum_{j=0}^{k} Q_{k}(\cos2\pi\theta_{j})\frac{\prod_{i\neq j} (x-\cos2\pi\theta_{i})}{\prod_{i\neq j}(\cos2\pi\theta_{j}-\cos2\pi\theta_{i})}.$$
**Definition 29** ($\epsilon$-uniform). The set $\{\theta_{j}\}_{j=0}^{k}\subset{\mathbb{T}}$ is called *$\epsilon$-uniform* if and only if $$\label{eq:epsunif} \max_{x\in[-1,1]}\max_{0\leq i\leq k}\prod_{j=0,j\neq i}^{k}\left|\frac{x-\cos2\pi\theta_{j}}{\cos2\pi\theta_{i}-\cos2\pi\theta_{j}}\right| Then the following result holds:
**Lemma 30**. *Let $0<\epsilon'<\epsilon$, $k\in{\mathbb{N}}_{+},$ and $\gamma>0$. If $\{\theta_{0},\cdots,\theta_{k}\}\subset A_{k}^{4\gamma'-\epsilon}$, then $\{\theta_{0},\cdots,\theta_{k}\}$ can not be $\epsilon'-$uniform for any sufficiently large $k$ such that $4k-2>k_{4}(\epsilon,\epsilon')$.*

*Proof.* If $\{\theta_{0},\cdots,\theta_{k}\}\subset A_{k}^{4\gamma'-\epsilon}$ is $\epsilon'$-uniform, then as a result of [langrange], we have the following estimates: $$\label{eq.Pestimate}|\Gamma^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,[1,4k-2]}(\theta+\frac{1}{4})|=|Q_{k}(\cos 2\pi(\theta+(k-1)\Phi)|\leq (k+1)e^{k(4\gamma'-(\epsilon-\epsilon'))}.$$ Compare this with Lemma 22 and Lemma 26: $$\label{eq.PlowerBound} \frac{1}{4k-2}\int\log |P^{\beta_{1},\beta_{2}}_{z,[1,4k-2]}(\theta)|d\theta\geq \gamma-\epsilon''$$ where $\epsilon''$ is arbitrarily small and $k$ sufficiently large. Then [eq.Pestimate] and [eq.PlowerBound] lead to a contradiction if we pick $\epsilon''<\frac{\epsilon-\epsilon'-4\eta}{5}$. ◻

Let $p_{n}/q_{n}$ be the sequence of continued fraction approximants of $2\Phi$, let $y$ be large enough, let $m$ be such that $q_{m}\leq \frac{y}{16} **Lemma 31**. *For any $\epsilon>0$, the set $\{\theta+2j\Phi\}_{j\in I_{1}\cup I_{2}}$ is $\epsilon$-uniform for $y>y_{0}(\Phi,\theta,\epsilon)$ sufficiently large.* The proof is standard, and we thus leave it to Appendix 8. Once we have this, we are ready to prove Lemma 24:

*Proof of Lemma 24.* Let $K=\max\{k_{1},k_{2},k_{3},k_{4}\}$ and let $y$ be sufficiently large such that $12sq_{m}-2>K$. By Lemma 30 and Lemma 31, $\{\theta+2j\Phi\}_{j\in I_{1}\cup I_{2}}$ cannot be inside the set $A_{3sq_{m}}^{4\gamma'-\frac{\epsilon}{8}}$. Since $0$ is $(\gamma-\epsilon,12sq_{m}-2)$-singular by the assumption $\Psi^{z}(0)\neq 0$, $y$ must be $(\gamma-\epsilon,12sq_{m}-2)$-regular, since if $y$ would be $(\gamma-\epsilon,12sq_{m}-2)$-2singular, the clusters of points given by Lemma 28 with respect to $0$ and $y$ would cover $I_{1}$ and $I_{2}$. This is a contradiction. Notice also that $12sq_{m}-2>\frac{5y}{16}$, so the proof can be completed. ◻
Decay Rate of Eigenfunctions In this section we prove that the eigenfunctions in the supercritical case decay at the Lyapunov rate:
**Theorem 32**. *For Diophantine $\Phi$, non-resonant $\theta$, and every eigenvalue $z\in I_{\mathrm{pp}}$ of $\mathcal E(\theta)$ as in Theorem [thm:mobs], the corresponding eigenfunction $\Psi^z=(\cdots,\Psi^{z}(2n),\Psi^{z}(2n+1),\cdots)$ satisfies $$\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1}{n} \log(|\Psi^{z}(2n)|^2 + |\Psi^{z}(2n+1)|^2) = -\frac{L(z)}{2}.$$*

Since every GECMV matrix is gauge equivalent to an extended CMV matrix $\tilde{\mathcal{E}}$ via a diagonal unitary transformation (see Theorem 1), we can use the normalized Szegő cocycle maps $S_{n,z}$ from [eq:szego_normalized] to compute the decay rate. By [eq.ConjugatedTransferMatrix] and Theorem 12, the corresponding Lyapunov exponent is $L(z)/2$. Let $\Psi^{z}$ be the solution to the eigenvalue equation of the extended CMV matrix $$\tilde{\mathcal{E}}\Psi^{z}=z\Psi^{z}.$$ It is a general result that $$\liminf\limits_{|n|\to\infty} \frac{\log(|\Psi^{z}(2n)|^{2}+|\Psi^{z}(2n+1)|)}{2|n|}\geq -\frac{L(z)}{2}.$$ Note that the factor $\frac{1}{2}$ on the right-hand side is due to our specific way of defining the Lyapunov exponent. Thus we only need to give an upper bound to prove Theorem 32. Such an upper bound follows from the block-resolvent expansion of , with the power law growth of the scales counteracting the combinatorial factor. However, in the present context this expansion is more involved.

Let $\Psi^{z}$ be the solution to the eigenvalue equation of the extended CMV matrix $$\tilde{\mathcal{E}}\Psi^{z}=z\Psi^{z}.$$ It is a general result that $$\liminf\limits_{|n|\to\infty} \frac{\log(|\Psi^{z}(2n)|^{2}+|\Psi^{z}(2n+1)|)}{2|n|}\geq -\frac{L(z)}{2}.$$ Note that the factor $\frac{1}{2}$ on the right-hand side is due to our specific way of defining the Lyapunov exponent. Thus we only need to give an upper bound to prove Theorem 32. Such an upper bound follows from the block-resolvent expansion of , with the power law growth of the scales counteracting the combinatorial factor. However, in the present context this expansion is more involved. To be more specific, let $\gamma=L(z)/2$ and $k_{5}$ be such that any $y$ with $|y|\geq k_{5}$ is $(\gamma-\epsilon,|y|)$- regular. To make the expansion clear, we use $i\in{\mathbb{N}}$ to track the times or levels of expansions, and $j\in{\mathbb{N}}$ to denote the index of endpoints of the interval in the definition of $(\gamma,k)$-regularity (Definition 23). Let $n_{i,j}$ stand for the $j$-th endpoint of $i$-th level of expansion counting from left to right, let $I(x)$ be the interval containing the $(\gamma-\epsilon,|x|)$-regular $x$ given in the definition of regularity, and $n_{i,j}'$ be either $n_{i,j}$ or the interior neighbor of $n_{i,j}$ that belongs to the interval which takes $n_{i,j}$ as one of its endpoints.

To make the expansion clear, we use $i\in{\mathbb{N}}$ to track the times or levels of expansions, and $j\in{\mathbb{N}}$ to denote the index of endpoints of the interval in the definition of $(\gamma,k)$-regularity (Definition 23). Let $n_{i,j}$ stand for the $j$-th endpoint of $i$-th level of expansion counting from left to right, let $I(x)$ be the interval containing the $(\gamma-\epsilon,|x|)$-regular $x$ given in the definition of regularity, and $n_{i,j}'$ be either $n_{i,j}$ or the interior neighbor of $n_{i,j}$ that belongs to the interval which takes $n_{i,j}$ as one of its endpoints. Denote $\tilde{G}_{I(x)}(x,\cdot)$ the Green’s function defined in [eq.GreenFunction]. It is immediate to check that if $n_{i,j}$ is $(\gamma-\epsilon,|n_{i,j}|)$-regular, then it is contained in an interval $[n_{i+1,2j-1},n_{i+1,2j}]$ with $|n_{i,j}-n_{i+1,c_{i,j}}|\geq \frac{1}{7}|n_{i,j}|$, where $c_{i,j}=2j-1$ or $2j$ standing for the left or right boundary, respectively. Let $r>1$, we start from a $y$ large enough and let $k_{6}$ be such that $k_{6}^{r}k_{5}$. Since $y$ is $(\gamma-\epsilon,|y|)$-regular, there exists $[n_{1,1},n_{1,2}]$ containing $y$ and satisfies $k_{6}<\frac{1}{7}k_{6}^{r-1}k_{6}-1\leq\frac{1}{7}y-1\leq n_{1,1}[eq.blockResolExp] below exceeds $7k_{6}^{r-1}$.

section_path: Absolutely Continuous Spectrum in the Subcritical Regime
text: # Absolutely Continuous Spectrum in the Subcritical Regime According to , the spectral measure of an extended CMV matrix with quasi-periodic Verblunsky coefficients is purely absolutely continuous continuous in the *subcritical* region. A key ingredient of is the analysis of the Szegő cocycle of the extended CMV matrix. Namely, if one has relatively “good" control on the growth of these cocycle, then the spectral measure can likewise be controlled. However, this argument does not apply directly to the mosaic UAMO with coefficients [eq:mosaicVerblunskies] for two reasons: Firstly, the doubly-infinite matrix corresponding to the mosaic UAMO is not a standard extended CMV matrix, since the $\rho$’s appearing therein are complex whenever $\lambda_2\neq1$, see [eq:mosaicVerblunskies]. Secondly, the coefficients in [eq:mosaicVerblunskies] are not quasi-periodic but merely almost-periodic.

heading.title: Absolutely Continuous Spectrum in the Subcritical Regime

section_path: Absolutely Continuous Spectrum in the Subcritical Regime
text: According to , the spectral measure of an extended CMV matrix with quasi-periodic Verblunsky coefficients is purely absolutely continuous continuous in the *subcritical* region. A key ingredient of is the analysis of the Szegő cocycle of the extended CMV matrix. Namely, if one has relatively “good" control on the growth of these cocycle, then the spectral measure can likewise be controlled. However, this argument does not apply directly to the mosaic UAMO with coefficients [eq:mosaicVerblunskies] for two reasons: Firstly, the doubly-infinite matrix corresponding to the mosaic UAMO is not a standard extended CMV matrix, since the $\rho$’s appearing therein are complex whenever $\lambda_2\neq1$, see [eq:mosaicVerblunskies]. Secondly, the coefficients in [eq:mosaicVerblunskies] are not quasi-periodic but merely almost-periodic. Fortunately, we can do away with the first obstacle by appealing to the gauge transform $D$ in Theorem 1. The second obstacle can be resolved by considering the four-step combined Szegő cocycle $(2\Phi,S^{++}_{e^{it}})$, which is quasi-periodic. Theorem 12 guarantees that $(2\Phi,S^{++}_{e^{it}})$ is subcritical for $e^{it}\in\Sigma$ whenever $F(\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},t)<0$, and that the behavior of the solution to the eigenvalue equation of the mosaic UAMO is the same as that of the corresponding extended CMV matrix with real $\rho$’s when the phase $\theta$ is complexified. We need the following global-to-local reduction lemma to turn the subcritical cocycles into perturbations of constant ones. Let $h>0$ be given, and for any function $f$ defined on $\{z\in{\mathbb{C}}:|{\mathrm{Im} \,}z| **Lemma 33**. *Let $\Phi\in {\mathrm{DC}}$, and let $\Sigma^{sub}$ be the set of spectral parameters for which the cocycle $(2\Phi,S^{++}_{e^{it}})$ is subcritical. Then there exists $h=h(2\Phi)>0$ such that for any $\eta>0$, and for any $e^{it}\in\Sigma^{sub}$, there exist $Z_{t}\in C^{\omega}(2{\mathbb{T}},{\mathbb{SU}}(1,1))$, $f_{t}(\theta)\in C^{\omega}({\mathbb{T}},\mathrm{su}(1,1))$, $\phi(t)\in{\mathbb{R}}$, $D_{\phi(t)}=\mathrm{diag}\{e^{i\phi(t)},e^{-i\phi(t)}\}$ such that $$\label{eq.conjugate} Z^{-1}_{t}(\theta+2\Phi)S^{++}_{e^{it}}(\theta)Z_{t}(\theta)=D_{\phi(t)}e^{f_{t}(\theta)}$$ with $\|f_{t}\|_{h}<\eta,\|Z_{t}\|_{h}<\Gamma(\Phi,\eta,\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2})$ for some constant $\Gamma$.*
